Headline: MBO Favorite To Buy Trinity Mirror Midland Titles - Newspaper
Story: LONDON (Dow Jones)--A private-equity backed management buyout team is favorite to buy Trinity Mirror PLC's (TNI.LN) portfolio of Midland newspaper titles, the Mail on Sunday reports without citing sources.   Exponent and Barclays Private Equity are the backers of the GBP190 million deal for papers including the Birmingham Post and Coventry Telegraph, the newspaper says.   Trinity Mirror, Exponent and Barclays Private Equity were not immediately available to comment.   Newspaper Web site: http://www.mailonsunday.co.uk   -London Bureau, Dow Jones Newswires; +44 (0)20 7842 9320     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 01, 2007 08:44 ET (12:44 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: =WSJ:Universal Music May Not Renew Long-term iTunes Contract
Story: By Ethan Smith and Nick Wingfield     Of THE WALL STREET JOURNAL     NEW YORK (Dow Jones)--Highlighting ongoing tension between the music industry and Apple Inc. (AAPL), Vivendi SA's (12777.FR) Universal Music Group is set to notify the Cupertino, Calif. company that it is not renewing a long term contract to sell digital music downloads through the increasingly powerful iTunes Store, according to people familiar with the situation, The Wall Street Journal has learned.   The move does not mean, however, that Universal will remove its vast catalog - including Eminem, 50 Cent and Sting - from iTunes in the foreseeable future. Instead, Universal, which is the world's largest music company by market share, expects to go to a short-term sales agreement.   Though it is unlikely to have sweeping effects immediately, the change could give Universal more flexibility in its dealings with competitors to iTunes - for instance enabling the company to offer other digital download stores parts of its catalog exclusively.   (This story and related background material will be available on The Wall Street Journal Web site, WSJ.com.)   Universal's move comes against a backdrop of dramatic change in the way music is sold. As traditional music retailers have fallen by the wayside, Apple has gained an outsize influence in music sales, recently becoming the No. 3 seller of recorded music to the public, behind Wal-Mart Stores Inc. and Best Buy Co. Inc. Its power has made record label executives increasingly uneasy, as it has generally refused to comply with labels' desire for flexibility on matters such as pricing.   As a result, the record labels and Apple have traded barbs with one another over the past year or so, with Apple Chief Executive Steve Jobs, for instance, calling record labels "greedy."   An Apple spokeswoman said the company doesn't comment "rumors and speculation."     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 01, 2007 21:58 ET (01:58 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Australia's Amcor Sells Europe PET Business FOR EUR425M
Story: MELBOURNE (Dow Jones)--Amcor Ltd. (AMC.AU) said Monday it has reached agreement to sell its European plastic soft drink bottling business to Spain's La Seda de Barcelona SA (SED.MC) for an estimated EUR425 million (US$575.4 million).   The sale is expected to be finalized in the third quarter of calendar 2007, the Melbourne-based company said in a statement.   In the year ended June 30, 2007, the business had unaudited sales of EUR545 million, earnings before interest, tax, depreciation and amortization of EUR60 million and earnings before interest and tax of EUR38 million, Amcor said.   The book value of the net assets sold plus transaction costs will be finalized after an audit in August and is expected to be about EUR260 million, it said.     -By Andrew Harrison, Dow Jones Newswires; 61-3-9671-4323; andrew.harrison@dowjones.com   -Edited by Paul Dekkers     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 01, 2007 19:20 ET (23:20 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: =WSJ: AT&T Working To Resolve iPhone Activation Problems
Story: By Amol Sharma and Nick Wingfield     Of THE WALL STREET JOURNAL     NEW YORK (Dow Jones)--AT&T Inc. (T) said it was working to resolve problems preventing some buyers of Apple Inc.'s (AAPL) iPhone from activating the device, illustrating the complexities Apple faces in working with a partner and in offering a consumer product that plugs into a cellular network.   The hiccup for one of the most eagerly awaited electronics products in years affected about 2% of those who purchased an iPhone, according to a person familiar with the situation. Phone activation also activates the iPhone's other features, such as playing music or movies and Web surfing.   (This story and related background material will be available on The Wall Street Journal Web site, WSJ.com.)   The problems likely would have to linger or broaden to blunt the overall impact of the iPhone for the two companies. Neither disclosed sales, although industry observers - citing crowded stores, media buzz and strong consumer interest - expect the new product to be a strong seller. Apple developed the iPhone device and its software, and AT&T has an exclusive, multiyear contract with Apple to provide cellular service for the device.   In blog postings and emails to The Wall Street Journal, some consumers who lined up at Apple and AT&T stores complained of problems and delays as they tried to get the phone running via Apple's iTunes computer software.   Some AT&T customers said their existing cellphones had been deactivated while they were still waiting for their iPhone to be activated, leaving them without any working phone.   AT&T spokesman Michael Coe said the vast majority of iPhone buyers were able to activate the device "within minutes." He added, "We're working to get those problems resolved. It's getting better and better."   "There are a small percentage of iPhone customers who have had a less-than-perfect activation experience," Apple spokeswoman Natalie Kerris said. "We're working hard to resolve any issues quickly."   Sheer volume appeared to cause general delays in AT&T's sign-up process, but there were some more specific problems. Some people who tried to port their numbers from rival carriers such as Verizon Wireless and T-Mobile USA got error messages and had to go through hours of customer support calls to fix the problem.   Some existing AT&T subscribers with business accounts said that, after hours of unsuccessfully trying to activate their iPhones, they found out belatedly that they would have to start entirely new personal accounts to use it.   Jared Gurfein, president of spirits company Viridian Spirits LLC, bought his iPhone at an Apple store Friday evening on New York's Long Island, Nassau County, N.Y., but hasn't been able to use the device since then. When he attempted to activate service with the iPhone online through iTunes, AT&T immediately stopped voice and email service for his existing BlackBerry phone, but Mr. Gurfein said the iPhone still wouldn't work, leaving him without a working cellphone. Mr. Gurfein said he had spent several hours on the phone with AT&T and Apple customer support representatives, to no avail."Both sides were passing the problem onto the other," he said.   "I'm at the point of frustration where, as much as I'd like to get the device to work, I'd just like to get my BlackBerry working again."   The problems for Jaci Russo, senior partner at the Russo Group, an advertising agency in Lafayette, Louisiana, also began when she attempted to switch to an iPhone she purchased Friday night from a BlackBerry she already had through AT&T. During the process, she received a message through iTunes that said her iPhone couldn't be activated because she had a business, not a personal, account with AT&T.   In the meantime, Ms. Russo lost voice and email service from her BlackBerry, until she finally got service through her iPhone turned on Saturday night after lengthy customer support calls to AT&T. There are still problems with service: Ms. Russo said two out of three phone calls she had received on her iPhone by Sunday, including one with a reporter, dropped out in mid-conversation. Calls to her iPhone number were answered by an automated message saying the phone number wasn't in service, before the phone began working again.   "I can't have that for work," she said. "My clients will freak out." She added, "IPhone is still a great thing, but it appears the service doesn't live up to the equipment."   The sign-up problems weren't the only glitch for AT&T in the iPhone launch. On Friday, its in-store sales systems temporarily stalled in areas up and down the East Coast because of an overload of activity.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 01, 2007 21:14 ET (01:14 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: WSJ(7/2) Stock Market Quarterly Review: Tech, Energy Shares Cruise To Big Gains
Story: (From THE WALL STREET JOURNAL)     By Carolyn Cui   Even as the Dow Jones Industrial Average hit some bumps on its way to rise 8.5% in the second quarter, there were stocks that racked up hefty gains.   Some benefited from rising oil prices or renewed interest in technology while others had company-specific stories to tell.   Among the quarter's best-performing companies was Flotek Industries Inc., a supplier of oil-field specialty chemicals and drilling tools, which more than doubled during the three months.   The Houston company made several acquisitions to expand its drilling-tool production capacity and said first-quarter revenue and earnings per share more than doubled from the previous year.   Foster Wheeler Ltd., which builds oil-and-gas processing facilities and natural-gas receiving terminals, saw its shares rise 83%, as the Clinton, N.J., company announced several construction contracts in China, Europe and Saudi Arabia.   The energy sector benefited from the 16% rise in oil prices this year. Although below their record high of about $77 a barrel last July, crude prices hit $70 during the latest quarter and ended the three-month period at $70.68 a barrel.   "The consensus believes that we are in a long-term chronic shortage of oil and energy," said James Paulsen, chief investment strategist at Wells Capital Management. "We have to build up new capacity, and new infrastructures." He said oil companies may be turning hefty profits earned in the past several years into new facilities.   The oil-and-gas sector rose 14%, the third-best performing sector in the quarter, after construction and materials and autos and auto parts, both of which rose more than 14%. The component oil-equipment and services industry gained 20%.   Parts of the technology sector also posted solid gains, with computer hardware up 15%. In the telecom sector, mobile telecommunications was up 10%.   American depositary shares of Nortel Inversora SA rose 83%. The Buenos Aires company's principal asset is a majority stake in a telecommunications-service provider in Argentina. Canadian wireless-modem maker Sierra Wireless Inc. surged 59% after it was awarded a contract from Fujitsu Siemens Computers BV, a venture between Fujitsu Ltd. and Siemens AG, and predicted stronger second-quarter earnings.   "Corporations are now flush with cash, and typically when that happens, companies will look for places to invest," said Bruce Bittles, chief investment strategist at Robert W. Baird & Co. "Capital spending is likely to increase as the year goes forward, and a lot of that will find its way into information-technology-type products."   It wasn't only companies serving businesses that posted gains. Rural Cellular Corp., an Alexandria, Minn., wireless-communication-services provider with a market value of $680 million, more than tripled after it restructured its balance sheet, expanded its coverage area in central and Midwestern states, and posted a narrower first-quarter loss than last year.   Investors in emerging markets also fared well, although some strategists see reasons for caution. Shares of Synutra International Inc., a Chinese maker of dairy-based nutritional products and infant formula, gained 74% after moving from the OTC Bulletin Board to the Nasdaq Stock Market in April. JA Solar Holdings Co., a solar-cells maker in China, surged 86% in the second quarter, after its February initial public offering of ADSs.   Among company-specific stories, Amazon.com Inc., rose 72% after its first-quarter earnings beat Wall Street expectations. The Seattle online retailer increased its profit margins by offering items from other retailers on its Web site, said Mayuresh Masurekar, an analyst following Internet and e-commerce with CIBC World Markets.   Seattle online-ad concern aQuantive Inc. more than doubled in the quarter after its share price shot up 78% in one day in late May, when Microsoft Corp. said it agreed to acquire the company for $6.3 billion.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 01, 2007 21:00 ET (01:00 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Story: SYDNEY (Dow Jones)--Macquarie Bank-backed Macquarie Communications Infrastructure Group (MCG.AU) said Monday it led a consotrium to acquire U.S.-based Global Tower Partners for US$1.425 billion.   In a statement, Sydney-based Macquarie Communications said it has taken a 28.7% in GTP, while partner Macquarie Infrastructure Partners will take 56.2%.   The remaining equity will be held by two other unlisted Macquarie funds and by GTP management.   "Through this acquisition Macquarie Communications has gained a timely position in a familiar industry in the attractive U.S. market," Macquarie Communciations Chief Executive Scott Davies.   Macquarie said GTP owns 2500 towers and 4600 rooftop sites for wireless communications in the U.S. and Puerto Rico.   The company said the acquisition will be funded by a combination of US$906 million equity, existing GTP debt of US$521 million and subordinated debt of US$110 million.   Macquarie Communications investment totals approximately A$444 million, including a contribution of subordinated debt of A$115 million and transaction costs of approximately A$18 million.   The deal is subject to U.S. regulatory approval.     -By Lyndal McFarland, Dow Jones Newswires; 61-2-8235-2957; lyndal.mcfarland@dowjones.com   -Edited by Paul Dekkers     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 01, 2007 19:22 ET (23:22 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Debenhams Mulls Linking With European Retailers - Newspaper
Story: LONDON (Dow Jones)--Department store chain Debenhams PLC (DEB.LN) has been secretly exploring a tie-up with European retailers, the Sunday Times reports without citing sources.   It says Debenhams, whose share price has fallen more than a third since floating last year, has approached retailers including department-store chains KarstadtQuelle (KAR.XE) of Germany, France's Galeries Lafayette and Italy's La Rinascente SpA.   Debenhams Chief Executive Rob Templeman has also been talking to private equity groups, the Sunday Times reports, adding that Templeman refused to comment on the plans. Any deal would need the support of Icelandic investment company Baugur Group, which holds a 4.87% stake in Debenhams and is also seen as a possible bidder for the company, the newspaper adds.   Debenhams was not immediately available to comment.   Newspaper Web site: http://www.timesonline.co.uk   -London Bureau, Dow Jones Newswires; +44 (0)20 7842 9320     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 01, 2007 07:25 ET (11:25 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Arab Invest Funds To Bid For Land Rover, Jaguar - Newspaper
Story: LONDON (Dow Jones)--Arab investment funds are drawing up bids for Land Rover and Jaguar, the U.K. car brands of Ford Motor Co. (F), the Observer reports Sunday without citing sources.   It says that Abu Dhabi's Mubadala Development Company and Dubai International Capital, have both instructed financial advisers to draw up plans to bid for one or both of the car brands, which Ford has put up for sale for more than GBP3 billion.   Neither fund was immediately available to comment.   Newspaper Web site: http://www.guardian.co.uk   -London Bureau, Dow Jones Newswires; +44 (0)20 7842 9320     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 01, 2007 08:01 ET (12:01 GMT)

Headline: Financial News: European Clearing And Settlement Tie-Ups Seen
Story: By William Wright and Luke Jeffs   Of FINANCIAL NEWS     Clearing and settlement organizations in Europe have started talks with each other about mergers, cooperation and alliances as they brace themselves for a wave of consolidation.   The talks have been prompted by regulatory pressure on the industry from the European Commission to end restrictive practices, an increase in competition between clearing and settlement organizations, and pressure from users to cut the high cost of what are collectively known as post-trade services, or the "plumbing" behind the financial markets.   The prospect of consolidation is important because the complex structure of clearing and settlement costs investors billions of euros a year and is a factor in holding up the creation of an integrated European cross-border financial market.   One senior clearing house executive said: "There is a febrile atmosphere over consolidation in the industry. Everyone is talking to everyone else at the moment."   Another said: "Consolidation has moved to the top of everyone's agenda. Organizations that were reluctant to talk to each other as recently as a few months ago are engaging in discussions. Regulation and the threat of competition have fundamentally changed the mindset of the industry."   At last week's Federation of European Securities Exchanges conference in Brussels, consolidation in post-trade services was one of the most keenly-discussed topics. Speculation focused on potential deals involving U.S. clearing house DTCC, Euroclear, the international clearing and settlement group, and LCH.Clearnet. All three declined to comment on any talks.   On the regulatory side, the European Commission is forcing the industry to end restrictive practices and open access to each other under a self-regulated code of conduct, which will be implemented at the beginning of next year.   This will allow clearing and settlement organizations to compete for each other's business and is a key part of the London Stock Exchange's plans for Borsa Italiana if its EUR1.6 billion acquisition, announced last week, goes through.     Web site: http://www.efinancialnews.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 01, 2007 20:01 ET (00:01 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: McDonald s To Power Trucks With Cooking Oil - FT
Story: DOW JONES NEWSWIRES     The oils that sizzle McDonald's fries and chicken nuggets will soon also stoke its trucks, as the fast food chain starts converting its cooking oil into biodiesel, the Financial Times reported on its Web site Monday.   McDonald's plans to run its 155 UK delivery trucks on biodiesel made entirely from cooking oil collected from its restaurants by the end of the year.   The fast-food group, which to date has been running trucks on 95% diesel and 5% biodiesel, will initially use a blend of 85% biodiesel and 15% rapeseed oil.   The company expects to convert an annual 6 million liters of oil, comparable with the 6.1 million liters of diesel used in its trucks last year.   It will collect oil from 900 of its 1,200 UK outlets each week, take it to a separation tank in East Anglia, where food particles will be removed, and then on to a biodiesel conversion plant in Milton Keynes in central England.       Newspaper Web site: http://www.ft.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 01, 2007 20:57 ET (00:57 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Centrica, Scottish & Southern Energy In Nuclear Tie-Up-Report
Story: LONDON (Dow Jones)--U.K. power companies Scottish & Southern Energy PLC (SSE.LN) and Centrica PLC (CNA.LN) have submitted a joint proposal to British Energy Group PLC (BGY.LN) to build a new generation of nuclear power stations, the Sunday Telegraph reports without citing sources.   Although neither firm generates nuclear power, they would offer British Energy access to retail customers, the newspaper adds.   British Energy has invited proposals from partners to help fund its investment in a GBP30 billion nuclear program, and the newspaper cites industry sources as saying it is likely to shortlist two consortia in the next month for detailed negotiations.   Centrica and Scottish & Southern Energy were not immediately available to comment.   Newspaper Web site: http://www.telegraph.co.uk   -London Bureau, Dow Jones Newswires; +44 (0)20 7842 9320     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 01, 2007 07:27 ET (11:27 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: WSJ(7/2) Northwest Moves To Reduce Flights, Hire More Pilots
Story: (From THE WALL STREET JOURNAL)     By Susan Carey   Northwest Airlines Corp., facing a string of more than 1,000 flight cancellations because of bad weather and a pilot shortage, said it plans to try to rectify the problem by cutting its summer capacity, redoubling efforts to increase its pilot ranks and modifying the way it schedules trips to minimize the effects of storms and air-traffic congestion on the rest of its network.   The airline began preemptively canceling large numbers -- 100 or more a day -- of its 1,400 daily mainline flights, or those with big jets, excluding commuter units and affiliates, late last month. From June 22 though Thursday, the carrier said it canceled 12% of its mainline flights. A normal rate would be 1% to 2% for all causes. Passengers fumed, even those who were contacted in advance and rebooked.   On Friday, Doug Steenland, Northwest's chief executive, said in a letter to employees the cumulative effect of the pilot shortage, storms and air-traffic congestion "left us no choice" but to cancel flights. Pilot absenteeism was up 40% in June compared with May and up 80% from a year earlier, with the increases primarily involving a minority of the airline's narrowbody aircraft pilots, he said.   The Eagan, Minn., carrier stepped out of bankruptcy-court protection a month ago with new, more productive labor contracts. It has been careful not to accuse the pilots of engaging in a concerted job action, and hasn't sought a court injunction to halt sick calls.   The Air Line Pilots Association, which represents Northwest's 5,000 active pilots, denied that its members are engaged in a job action. It blamed short staffing and an aggressive flight schedule that pushes pilots to fly a high number of hours, close to the maximum allowed under U.S. rules. A spokesman said he couldn't comment on the absentee numbers the chief executive cited.   Mr. Steenland said Northwest will drop its second daily flight on July 18 from Detroit to Frankfurt. In August, it will cut its domestic mainline capacity by 3% by reducing the maximum hours pilots will be asked to fly that month.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 01, 2007 19:50 ET (23:50 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: UPDATE: Australia's Amcor Sells Europe PET Unit For EUR425M
Story: (Adds background)       By Andrew Harrison     Of DOW JONES NEWSWIRES     MELBOURNE (Dow Jones)--Amcor Ltd. (AMC.AU), the world's largest maker of plastic soft drink bottles, said Monday it has agreed to sell its European PET business to Spain's La Seda de Barcelona SA (SED.MC) for an estimated EUR425 million (US$575.4 million).   The sale is expected to be finalized in the third quarter of calendar 2007, the Melbourne-based company said in a statement.   Melbourne-based Amcor has sold A$420 million of assets and closed 10 plants as part of a three-year program to "fix, close or sell" non-performing units. It flagged the sale of all or part of its European PET unit in February, saying it would raise up to A$580 million.   Amcor became the world's largest maker of plastic soft drink bottles when it bought the European business from Schmalbach-Lubeca AG in 2002 for A$2.8 billion along with other assets in North and South America.   The company has been restructuring its business because its earnings have been crimped by higher costs for transport, energy, pulp and resin, while it has been trying to maintain its share of markets, which rivals have targeted.   As part of its three-year restructuring program, Amcor has been improving the efficiency of its Latin American soft drink bottle unit, European flexibles and Australasian fiber packaging businesses.   Barcelona-based Seda is one of Europe's largest producers of artificial and synthetic fabrics and yarns, such as polyester, polythene and viscose.   The company, which has founded in 1925 in order to produce silk for Rayón Viscosa, is also involved in pharmaceutical fields, such as the production of oxyacetylene and its derivatives.   Earlier this year Seda acquired Eastman Chemical Co's Spanish business for EUR40.5 million to boost its annual production PET capacity to 1 million tonnes.   Amcor's PET business in the year ended June 30 had unaudited sales of EUR545 million, earnings before interest, tax, depreciation and amortization of EUR60 million and earnings before interest and tax of EUR38 million, the company said.   The book value of the net assets sold plus transaction costs will be finalized after an audit in August and is expected to be about EUR260 million, Amcor said.     -By Andrew Harrison, Dow Jones Newswires; 61-3-9671-4323; andrew.harrison@dowjones.com   -Edited by Paul Dekkers     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 01, 2007 19:55 ET (23:55 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Japan's Honda Motor May Review This FY Profit Forecast -Exec
Story: By Nitin Luthra   Of DOW JONES NEWSWIRES     TAPUKARA, India (Dow Jones)--Japan's Honda Motor Co. Ltd. (7267.TO) may review its current year's profit forecast announced in April as the yen has weakened against the U.S. dollar, Honda Chairman Satoshi Aoki said Sunday.   "We may want to review our forecast. I'm not saying we will revise but we may review if we need to revise our forecast," Aoki said in response to a query on the company's statement in April that Honda may suffer a 2.9% fall in profit in the current fiscal year to March 2008.   Honda earns about 70% of its profit from the U.S., so a weaker yen boosts its earnings by increasing the value of sales made outside Japan.   Aoki is in India to participate in the ceremony for the laying of the foundation stone of Honda's second car plant in the country, in the western state of Rajasthan.   The Japanese automaker operates in India via Honda Siel Cars India Ltd., in which it owns a 99.9% stake while the remaining 0.1% is held by Siel Ltd. (523371.BY).   Honda had based its forecast on an assumed average dollar rate of Y115 against the then-prevailing rate of Y117, Aoki said.   "Now that the yen since then has been trading weaker than Y115, that should give us some favorable impact," he said.   When asked about rising prices of commodities, which have eaten into margins of automakers globally, Aoki said "some amount of negative impact" is coming from rising costs of materials such as aluminum and copper.   He added that Honda was taking steps to boost internal efficiencies and save costs, but didn't elaborate.   Honda Siel, which sells the City, Civic and Accord sedans and the CR-V sports utility in India, earlier said it will invest up to $460 million to build and expand its second plant as it tries to garner more market share in the country's booming automobile industry.   But initially only 10 billion rupees ($230 million) will be invested to build a startup annual production capacity of 60,000 units, the company said Sunday, adding that annual capacity could be increased to 200,000 units on strong demand.   Honda will use the plant to mark its foray into India's high-volume small or compact car segment, which according to industry officials dominates overall car sales with a nearly 80% market share.   Honda's small car, which is expected to roll out of the Rajasthan plant in late 2009, will boast local content of up to 90%, Honda Siel's President and Chief Executive Masahiro Takedagawa said.   Passenger vehicle sales in India are forecast to nearly double to 2 million units by 2010 due on rising incomes and new launches including that of cars costing just INR100,000 ($2,500) - which is about half the price of the cheapest car currently sold in India.   Companies like Tata Motors Ltd. (500570.BY) have already begun work on such ultra-low cost car projects. Last week, Nissan Motor Co. (7201.TO) Chief Executive Carlos Ghosn said India's Mahindra & Mahindra Ltd. (500520.BY) will likely be its partner for a low-price car project for India.   However, Aoki said it will be a challenge to make cars at such low prices.   "A 660-cubic-centimeter mini car in Japan costs around $9,000...to make something at one third this cost is rather challenging," he said. "Personally, I'd be surprised to see such a kind of model."   Honda Siel is also doubling manufacturing capacity at its plant near New Delhi to 100,000 units by the end of this year and expects to make 150,000 units a year beginning in 2010, on the combined capacity offered by both plants.   However, the company has no plans to export small cars from India.   "We don't have any plan on that as our philosophy is to make cars wherever the demand is. But it is possible that we may export certain components of a small car as it will be a global model," Takedagawa said.     -By Nitin Luthra, Dow Jones Newswires; +91-98100-65468; nitin.luthra@dowjones.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 01, 2007 12:02 ET (16:02 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: UPDATE: Australia Wesfarmers In Talks On Solo Bid For Coles
Story: (Adds comment by Wesfarmers, detail)       By Susan Murdoch     Of DOW JONES NEWSWIRES     MELBOURNE (Dow Jones)--Australia's Wesfarmers Ltd. (WES.AU) is locked in talks Monday about a potential solo bid for retailer Coles Group Ltd. (CGJ.AU), which could be valued at up to A$20.8 billion.   Wesfarmers, an industrial conglomerate, was forced to go it alone in its bid for Coles after London-based partner Permira (PR.YY) pulled out, citing the state of U.S. financing market.   Permira, along with local buyout company Pacific Equity Partners and Australia's Macquarie Bank Ltd., had planned to take a 50% stake in Coles' core "Everyday Needs" business; supermarkets, liquor stores and discount chain Kmart.   The last minute withdrawal of Permira ahead of Saturday's bid deadline means Wesfarmers will now increase the planned scrip component of its offer to help fund the deal, a person familiar with the situation told Dow Jones Newswires.   If it succeeds, the takeover would be the biggest in Australia's history.   Without citing its sources, the Australian Financial Review reported Monday that Wesfarmers has offered a A$20.8 billion cash and scrip proposal, which, depending on the level of shares investors take, values Coles between A$16.00 a share and A$17.00-A$17.25 a share.   Wesfarmers paid A$16.47 a share for a 12.8% stake in Coles in April.   A spokesman for Wesfarmers said it remains in talks with Pacific Equity Partners, but the buyout company is unlikely to take an equity stake.   Macquarie remains an adviser to Wesfarmers.   Pacific Equity Partners' continuing role is important, as its director Steven Cain is a former head of Coles' supermarket division. Cain was expected to play a key role in resurrecting the business.   Shares in Wesfarmers and Coles are in trading halts pending the outcome of takeover talks. Wesfarmers shares have been rising in recent weeks on expectations it had the upper hand in the Coles bargaining process following the exit of its main bidding rival, a buyout consortium led by TPG Inc.   Wesfarmers closed Friday at A$45.73, Coles shares ended at A$16.12.   Some traders expressed concern over the large portion of risk Wesfarmers would shoulder following the exit of the Permira.   "It has raised the stakes since private equity has pulled out - A$12 billion of equity and A$8 billion of debt - it's all on their shoulders," said one trader, who declined to be named. "I would have thought this is a big bite for Wesfarmers and I'd be shocked if its (shares) keep pushing up. I think the share price should go down. It won't be an easy turnaround if it's all on the balance sheet."   Woolworths Ltd., Coles' main rival, also lodged a bid for parts of the Coles business. Competition rules would prevent Woolworths from bidding for Coles' core food and liquor assets, with the two companies controlling around 70% of Australia's supermarket industry.   Wesfarmers was the only company bidding for the whole company following the exit of the TPG consortium last week. TPG also blamed the rising cost of the U.S. debt market for its decision.   Concerns of a global credit squeeze were heightened last week by the near-collapse of two hedge funds run by U.S. investment bank Bear Stearns.       -By Susan Murdoch, Dow Jones Newswires; 61-3-9671-4393; susan.murdoch@dowjones.com     -Edited by Graham Morgan     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 01, 2007 23:58 ET (03:58 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Sojitz To Invest About Y14B In Australia Coal Devt Ops-Nikkei
Story: TOKYO (Nikkei/Dow Jones)--Sojitz Corp. (2768.TO) plans to invest about Y14 billion in large-scale coal mining development at its joint operations in Australia, the Nikkei reported in its Monday morning edition.   On top of the Y9 billion in rights that Sojitz will take, the company is expected to bear the burden of about Y5 billion worth of the approximately Y50 billion development costs needed.   At its peak operating rate, the project is expected to annually produce about 1,200 metric tons of thermal coal.   Sojitz is expected to sell about 500 tons of the thermal coal in Asia on an annual basis.   Production at the project, which is in tandem with Felix Resources Ltd. (FLX.AU), is expected to begin in 2009 and reach full capacity in 2011.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 01, 2007 19:32 ET (23:32 GMT)

Headline: Kuwait Phone Company MTC Eyes London IPO -Newspaper
Story: DOW JONES NEWSWIRES   MTC, the Kuwaiti telecoms group, will announce plans Monday for an initial public offering in London, according to The Times in London on Monday.   The GBP14.9 billion telecoms group, which is Vodafone Group PLC's (VOD) partner in the Middle East, hopes to float MTCI, its international vehicle, in London in 2008, according to the newspaper.   In a visit to London Monday, Saad al-Barrak, MTC's chief executive, is expected to outline plans to raise about EUR3 billion, according to the newspaper.   He will also unveil plans for a rebranding, under which the group will drop the Vodafone name from its operations in Bahrain and Kuwait, the newspaper said. The move is thought to have been prompted by the Kuwaiti company's desire to further distinguish itself as a strong player in its own right, the newspaper said.   The group will also announce its intention to compete for licenses against Vodafone, The Times said.   Newspaper Web site: http://timesonline.co.uk   -Dow Jones Newswires; dennis.baker@dowjones.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 01, 2007 22:29 ET (02:29 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Kraft In Talks To Buy Danone's Biscuit,Cereal Ops - Report
Story: DOW JONES NEWSWIRES   Kraft Foods Inc. Headline: Financial News: HSBC Sends Signal Of Intent With India Stake
Story: By Duncan Kerr   Of FINANCIAL NEWS     HSBC (HBC) has taken one of its first stakes in a private company from an investment fund it is raising, as the U.K.-based bank looks to further expand in buyouts.   It has invested $100 million of its own equity through the fund to take at least part of a 15% stake of the mobile telecommunications tower business of India's Reliance Communications (532712.BY). Reliance wanted to more than double the number of its masts to 37,000 by the end of next year.   The deal for Reliance Telecom Infrastructure, a subsidiary of the Indian telecoms operator, comes four weeks after it invited bids from strategic investors and private equity firms.   Interest in the company, which owns and manages some 14,000 mobile telecom towers in India, is understood to have come from Deutsche Bank's principal investment arm and buyout groups Apax Partners, Carlyle Group, Tiger Brokerage and Blue Ridge Partners.   American Tower and Israel's Tower Vision also requested information memorandums.   Web site: http://www.efinancialnews.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 01, 2007 20:01 ET (00:01 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: WSJ(7/2) UPDATE: Some IPhones Are Stuck On Hold
Story: (From THE WALL STREET JOURNAL)     By Amol Sharma and Nick Wingfield   AT&T Inc. said it was working to resolve problems preventing some buyers of Apple Inc.'s iPhone from activating the device, illustrating the complexities Apple faces in working with a partner and in offering a consumer product that plugs into a cellular network.   The hiccup for one of the most eagerly awaited electronics products in years affected about 2% of those who purchased an iPhone, according to a person familiar with the situation. Phone activation also activates the iPhone's other features, such as playing music or movies and Web surfing.   The problems likely would have to linger or broaden to blunt the overall impact of the iPhone for the two companies. Neither disclosed sales, although industry observers -- citing crowded stores, media buzz and strong consumer interest -- expect the new product to be a strong seller. Apple developed the iPhone device and its software, and AT&T has an exclusive, multiyear contract with Apple to provide cellular service for the device.   In blog postings and emails to The Wall Street Journal, some consumers who lined up at Apple and AT&T stores complained of problems and delays as they tried to get the phone running via Apple's iTunes computer software.   Some AT&T customers said their existing cellphones had been deactivated while they were still waiting for their iPhone to be activated, leaving them without any working phone.   AT&T spokesman Michael Coe said the vast majority of iPhone buyers were able to activate the device "within minutes." He added, "We're working to get those problems resolved. It's getting better and better."   "There are a small percentage of iPhone customers who have had a less-than-perfect activation experience," Apple spokeswoman Natalie Kerris said. "We're working hard to resolve any issues quickly."   Jared Gurfein, president of spirits company Viridian Spirits LLC, bought his iPhone at an Apple store Friday on New York's Long Island, but hasn't been able to use the device since then. "I'm at the point of frustration where, as much as I'd like to get the device to work, I'd just like to get my BlackBerry working again."     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 01, 2007 22:34 ET (02:34 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Financial News: Left In Dark By Blackstone Research Blackout
Story: By William Wright   A FINANCIAL NEWS Column     The collapse in shares in Blackstone Group (BX) since the private equity group's flotation has highlighted the unintended consequences of well-intended regulation.   After an initial public offering in the U.S., the lead banks are not allowed to publish research for 40 days and other banks in the syndicate must keep their mouths shut for 25 days.   The regulations are designed to prevent a false market because investors would face a barrage of redundant buy recommendations from the banks leading the deal. It is also best practice for banks not involved in the deal not to publish research during this blackout. However, in a world in which research has been "Napsterized" by the Internet, as the head of research at Merrill Lynch famously said this year, something will fill that vacuum.   In the case of Blackstone, it has been filled by unremittingly negative and often ill-informed coverage in the media and the blogosphere. In a post-Spitzer world of separation between investment banking and research, it seems absurd to continue to apply this blackout.   Analysts who are not allowed to publish research are no doubt talking to their preferred clients on it - the sort of behavior the rules are designed to prevent. U.S. authorities are considering a reduction in the blackout to 25 days. They should go further. They should encourage - perhaps force - companies to provide access to independent research firms before and immediately after they list.   editor@efinancialnews.com     Web site: http://www.efinancialnews.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 01, 2007 20:01 ET (00:01 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: WSJ(7/2) Fund Track: What Makes A China Fund A China Fund?
Story: (From THE WALL STREET JOURNAL)     By Carolyn Cui and Tom Lauricella   The Chinese stock market has been on a tear the past year, but China-focused mutual funds are lagging far behind.   The average China stock fund is up 25% so far this year, according to fund researcher Lipper Inc. That is pretty good, except the Shanghai Composite Index is up almost twice as much -- 46% -- despite having fallen 10% in recent weeks from its May record.   The reason for the discrepancy speaks volumes about the limits put on foreign-investor access in the booming economy. It also highlights the importance for investors to understand what they are getting in funds like these.   Most China funds invest the vast majority of their money -- and in at least one case, 100% of the portfolio -- in Chinese companies traded in Hong Kong and other markets outside the mainland. Those markets tend to more closely track movements in the U.S. stock market than in the mainland Chinese exchanges. Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index is up 9.9% this year.   Chinese-government regulations tightly limit the amount of money foreign investors can put into mainland stocks. In addition, fund managers have their own reasons for not diving too deeply into China shares: They cite concerns about lax regulation on mainland exchanges, lofty prices and a tendency for the shares to have huge swings in prices.   "There are many types of Chinese stocks, but most investors don't quite understand the difference" between them all, said Richard Gao, portfolio manager of the $1.24 billion Matthews China Fund.   China's mainland market consists of two classes of shares. A large majority are Class A shares traded in yuan, the Chinese currency. Most A shares are traded by local investors; non-Chinese investors must apply for permission to own them, and then the government places strict limits on foreign ownership.   A smaller market of Class B shares, denominated in dollars, is open to non-Chinese investors. Shares of mainland-Chinese companies that are traded in Hong Kong are known as H shares, or "red chips" if the companies are both listed and incorporated in Hong Kong.   Fund companies don't make it easy for investors to figure which kinds of stocks their funds own. They often simply categorize investments as in "China" or "Hong Kong" -- although sometimes "China" investments actually trade on Hong Kong's stock exchange. For example, the $90 million AIM China Fund lists 66% of its assets as in China and 25% in Hong Kong, but only 8% are A or B shares trading on mainland exchanges.   "Every time we have a company incorporated in China and doing business in China, even though they are listed in Hong Kong, we list those companies as being in China," a spokesman for AIM said.   It is a similar story for the Dreyfus Premier Greater China fund -- this year's best-performing China fund, up 39% so far in 2007. It tells investors that 57% of the portfolio is in China and 28% in Hong Kong. Portfolio manager Hugh Simon says the fund actually has only 19% in China's B-share market. The fund holds just one A-share stock.   Mr. Simon said the fund's focus is on each company's fundamentals, not where it trades. "We invest in greater China."   The $801 million Oberweis China Opportunities Fund doesn't own a single stock traded on the mainland exchanges, according to manager James Oberweis. "Many higher-quality Chinese companies list their shares in Hong Kong," he said.   In general, fund managers prefer to invest in Hong Kong-listed companies because of the city's more stringent regulatory oversight of the market.   "The overall quality of Hong Kong-listed Chinese companies is higher than that of A-share companies," Mr. Gao said.   Then there is volatility. In late May, mainland Chinese stocks tumbled a total of 15% in four sessions, while Hong Kong stocks edged up 2%. Although volatility can benefit investors when stocks shoot higher, sharp swings in price can make it difficult for a fund to trade.   Such swings are the result of a market dominated by more than 100 million individual investors, accounting for about two-thirds of the daily volume. "We expect high volatility to persist in the . . . A-shares markets," said Samantha Ho, manager of the AIM China Fund.   In part because of such concerns, some funds have restrictions built into their prospectuses that limit their holdings. Matthews China can invest only 10% in B shares, and AIM China is restricted to no more than 10% of the fund in A shares.   Having missed out on the big run-up, many fund managers now worry that mainland stocks are overvalued and as a result it isn't a good time for them to buy. "Valuations of A shares are somewhat stretched," says Ms. Ho. "We believe there are good buying opportunities in [Hong Kong-listed stocks] where valuations are reasonable."     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 01, 2007 23:02 ET (03:02 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: French Govt To Decide On Suez/GdF In Next 15 Days -Report
Story: PARIS (Dow Jones)--The French government will make a decision in the next fifteen days on the planned merger of French-Belgian utility company Suez (12052.FR) and state-owned natural gas and electricity company Gaz de France (1020848.FR), the French presidency's secretary general Claude Gueant said in an interview to be published Monday in French daily La Tribune.   The decision will be made "within the next fifteen days," Gueant said, adding that "it is not correct to say the government has already taken a position" on the merger.   The government is to hold more meetings in the next week, Gueant added.   French Prime Minister Francois Fillon said Friday the "initial scenario" of a merger between the two utilities "has good reasons to exist but there are other" possible scenarios.   Newspaper Web site: www.latribune.fr   -By Paris Bureau, Dow Jones Newswires; +33 1 4017 1740     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 01, 2007 15:18 ET (19:18 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Mediobanca's Nagel, Pagliaro To Run Bk; Galateri Out -Report
Story: DOW JONES NEWSWIRES   Alberto Nagel, currently general manager at Mediobanca SpA (MB.MI) and Renato Pagliaro, co-general manager at the bank, will be named chief executive officer and chairman, respectively, by the newly created supervisory board, reports La Repubblica in its Monday Internet edition.   Meanwhile, Mediobanca's current non-executive chairman, Gabriele Galateri di Genola, will have to step down, the paper adds.   Shareholders of Mediobanca Wednesday approved a new dual governance structure and, controversially, appointed Capitalia SpA (CAP.MI) Chairman Cesare Geronzi as head of one of its two boards.   By switching from a single board to a dual-governance structure - with a supervisory board and a management board - Mediobanca's management hopes to avert potential conflicts of interest arising from the bank's position at the center of a complex web of shareholdings, reflected in its own board membership.   Newspaper Web site: http://www.corriere.it   -Dow Jones Newswires; enza.tedesco@dowjones.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 01, 2007 22:05 ET (02:05 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Trans Fat Ban, Calorie Display Rule Take Effect In NYC
Story: NEW YORK (AP)--The city's ban on trans fat-laden cooking oils, the first of its kind in the nation, went into effect Sunday.   Along with the ban, fast-food restaurants in New York City now must post calories on their menu. Few eateries, however, were complying with the calorie rule.   Most fast-food chains reversed their initial opposition to the trans fat ban and implemented it ahead of Sunday's deadline, the city Health Department reported.   The first phase applies to oils, shortening and margarine used for frying and spreading - not to baked goods or prepared foods, or oils used to deep-fry dough or cake batter. These are covered by the second phase of the regulation, which takes effect on July 1, 2008.   Since New York passed the ban last year, Philadelphia, Montgomery County in Maryland and the Boston suburb of Brookline have followed its lead with similar measures that take effect later this year or in 2008. Several other states and cities including California and Chicago are also considering trans fat prohibitions.   Leaflets tacked onto the wall at one McDonald's said, "0 Grams Trans Fat and Still Loving the Taste!" But the restaurant kept the nutritional information off the menus, relegating it to a chart on the back of the fliers: 740 calories for a Quarter Pounder with cheese, 620 for a McFlurry.   Even the leaflets were not in evidence at nearby McDonald's restaurants in midtown Manhattan. "I have no comment," said a manager at 10th Avenue and 34th Street.   McDonald's Corp. (MCD) and Burger King Holdings Inc. (BKC) were among the chains refusing to follow the new rule requiring certain fast food restaurants to list calorie counts next to menu items in type that is at least as large as the price.   With city officials not planning to issue fines for violations of the new rules until Oct. 1, most chains seem to be holding out in the hopes that a New York Restaurant Association federal lawsuit will get the calorie rule thrown out.   In the lawsuit, the eateries argue that their First Amendment rights were being violated, and complained that the rule would turn each of their menu boards into a cluttered mess.   At one Burger King restaurant on Sunday, the nutritional information including calories was posted on a wall where few customers waiting to order their food appeared to notice it.   If they had, they could have learned that a triple Whopper with cheese has 1,230 calories - 1,070 without mayonnaise - and a king-size chocolate shake has 1,260. The recommended daily calorie intake for an adult woman is about 1,800.   Lowell Stephens, a manager at the Burger King, said the information had been posted in the restaurant for at least a year and a half.   "A lot of people know that it's there," he said. "They can read it any time."   But when the city does start cracking down, posting the calories on a chart on the wall won't be good enough.   "It needs to be at the point of purchase," Health Department spokesman Andrew Tucker said Sunday. "The point being that customers can actually see it when they're deciding what to order."   Starbucks (SBUX) was offering a compromise. The chain's 220 New York City coffee shops will offer nutritional information on spiral-bound flip books set up on the counters where customers get their milk and sugar, spokesman Brandon Borrman said.   Borrman said putting calorie counts on the menu would be problematic.   "The menu boards become very visually complex when you do that," he said.   Subway, which has marketed itself as a healthier alternative to other types of fast food, is complying with the regulation and began putting up new menus including calorie counts at its 340 New York City locations in the past few days.   "We've always been upfront about our nutritional information," said Les Winograd, a spokesman with the chain, which is owned by the Milford, Conn.-based Doctor's Associates Inc.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 01, 2007 20:30 ET (00:30 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Carlyle Group In Talks To Acquire Virgin Media - NYT
Story: NEW YORK (Dow Jones)--Carlyle Group L.P. is said to be in talks acquire Virgin Media (VMED), The New York Times reports on its Web site Sunday.   According to the report, Carlyle's potential bid could be worth around $20 billion, a person familiar with the negotiations said.   According to the source, the talks are still in their early stages and may not lead to a bid, the Times said.   A spokeswoman for Virgin Media declined to comment, the Times said.   Newspaper Web site: http://www.nytimes.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 01, 2007 20:51 ET (00:51 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: : Secure Computing Warns: iPhone Release Immediately Followed By New Web-Borne Malware Threat
Story: SAN JOSE, Calif., July 1 /PRNewswire-FirstCall/ -- Secure Computing Corporation (Nasdaq: SCUR), a leading enterprise gateway security company, today warned that email spam, indicating that the recipient has won a new iPhone, is directing users to a malware hosting website.     Secure Computing has discovered a website that is attempting to exploit over 10 Active X vulnerabilities in its efforts to install a malicious payload including the MSODataSourceControl vulnerability that Secure Computing warned users about only 2 weeks ago.  The website is tracking visitors on the site and then redirecting repeat visitors to a different, clean webpage in efforts to thwart security researchers as well as using XOR encryption to obfuscate the attack.     "This yet again confirms the expanding trend in web-borne malware," said Paul Henry, vice president of technology evangelism for Secure Computing. "This threat is particularly insidious in that scripts within the HTML code returned to the user contain exploit code for multiple vulnerabilities to improve the malicious hacker's chances of gaining the necessary access to install the rootkit /spam bot malware. While most organizations fully inspect the traffic directed to their Internet facing web servers, many do not inspect the traffic that is returned to their internal users when visiting Internet web sites."     The initial activity of the rootkit/spam bot malware is to incorporate the compromised PC into a spam sending botnet. Because the malware is rootkit- based, it would be a simple matter for the malicious hacker to at any time update the malware to include other nefarious tasks, such as key logging on the compromised PC to capture the user's financial credentials for use in ID theft.     Viruses, worms, Trojans and other malware have traditionally been distributed over email with further propagation through each compromised users' email address books and made to look like messages coming from them. "With this threat, we again see the addition of a web attack component to traditional email-based malware," said Henry. "Secure Computing has recently seen other evidence of web-borne malware propagating through the use of fake video-hosting sites and fake greeting card messages."     "Because of the popularity of the iPhone brand this is the first in what's bound to be a series of scams involving the iPhone," added Henry.     Customers using Secure Computing's Webwasher(R), the industry's first and only reputation-based Web gateway security solution, are protected against this.  Webwasher protects enterprises from spyware, phishing, malware, data leakage, and Internet misuse, while ensuring policy enforcement, regulatory compliance, and a productive application environment. It incorporates global intelligence from the company's industry-leading reputation system, TrustedSource(TM), which provides source-based reputation scores for web page content, messages, attachments and images.  Webwasher employs the most sophisticated behavioral and signature-based techniques for stopping malware, as well as patented content analysis software for stopping data leakage.        About Secure Computing:     Secure Computing (Nasdaq: SCUR), a leading provider of enterprise gateway security, delivers a comprehensive set of solutions that help customers protect their critical Web, email and network assets. Over half the Fortune 50 and Fortune 500 are part of our more than 20,000 global customers in 106 countries, supported by a worldwide network of more than 2,300 partners. The company is headquartered in San Jose, Calif., and has offices worldwide. For more information, see http://www.securecomputing.com.     This press release contains forward-looking statements relating to the Secure Computing's timely identification of security threats and its ability to protect against such threats, and such statements involve a number of risks and uncertainties. Among the important factors that could cause actual results to differ materially from those indicated by such forward-looking statements are delays in product development, undetected software errors or bugs, competitive pressures, technical difficulties, changes in customer requirements, general economic conditions and the risk factors detailed from time to time in Secure Computing's periodic reports and registration statements filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission.     All trademarks or tradenames used herein belong to their respective owners.           Ally Zwahlen                         Paula Dunne       Secure Computing Corporation         Contos Dunne Communications LLC       925-288-4175                         408-776-1400; 408-893-8750 cell       ally_zwahlen@securecomputing.com     paula@contosdunne.com           (Logo: http://www.newscom.com/cgi-bin/prnh/20060808/LATU027LOGO)      SOURCE  Secure Computing Corporation       /CONTACT: Ally Zwahlen of Secure Computing Corporation, +1-925-288-4175, ally_zwahlen@securecomputing.com; or Paula Dunne of Contos Dunne Communications LLC, +1-408-776-1400; +1-408-893-8750 cell, paula@contosdunne.com      /Web site: http://www.securecomputing.com/     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 01, 2007 23:59 ET (03:59 GMT)

Headline: WSJ(7/2) Bear Stearns Investors Await Tally On Losses
Story: (From THE WALL STREET JOURNAL)     By E.S. Browning   Investors in two Bear Stearns hedge funds will have to wait until as late as July 16 to learn how much money they have lost.   The Wall Street firm has had difficulty calculating the funds' fair value, apparently because many of the mortgage-related securities they hold are thinly traded and the market for them has been volatile.   "In light of the Funds' circumstances, this process is more time-consuming than in prior periods," Bear's asset-management arm said in a "Dear Investor" letter dated Friday. It told investors that net asset values as of May 31 would be calculated "on or before July 16," and that it would make its best effort to calculate an estimate of the June 30 value of the two funds by the same time.   It "has determined not to release an estimated NAV in the interim," Bear Stearns Asset Management Inc. said in the letter.   A Bear Stearns official declined to comment on the letter.   Investors are watching the process closely because they believe that other hedge funds also are holding thinly traded mortgage-related securities, and they want to see how far Bear thinks their value has fallen.   Last month, the more indebted of the two funds, the Bear Stearns High Grade Structured Credit Strategies Enhanced Leverage fund, reported that its value fell 6.75% in April. Two weeks later, it put the loss at 18%. Values are believed to have fallen further since then, and the declines have caused some investors to flee funds that make such investments.   As of March 31, the Enhanced Leverage fund had $638 million in investor capital and at least $6 billion in borrowings. It used the money to make $11.5 billion in bullish bets and $4.5 billion in bearish bets, according to documents reviewed by The Wall Street Journal.   Its sister fund, the Bear Stearns High Grade Structured Credit Strategies fund, had $925 million in investor money, and made $9.7 billion in bullish bets and $4 billion in bearish bets.   In an effort to support the latter fund, which has fewer loans and is considered easier to salvage, Bear Stearns has announced that it would take over $1.6 billion of the fund's debt, which Bear said is collateralized.   In June, the two funds were forced to sell about $4 billion of assets to meet margin calls, which are calls to repay debt to brokers.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 01, 2007 19:44 ET (23:44 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: WSJA(7/2) Bank Of Ayudhya CEO Keeps Focus On Teamwork
Story: (From THE WALL STREET JOURNAL ASIA)     By James Hookway   When GE Money, the consumer-finance unit of General Electric Co., completed its $626 million investment in Thailand's sixth-largest bank this year, it seconded dozens of executives to help build up the business of its new strategic ally, Bank of Ayudhya PCL. Among them was Tan Kong Khoon, the bank's new president and chief executive.   With GE Money's 25.4% equity stake and a brief to help the family-controlled Bank of Ayudhya expand beyond its strong corporate base and increase its consumer lending, Mr. Tan, 50 years old, took over the helm of the bank in March. His goal: to draw on his long experience in Asian banking, including stints in China with Citigroup's Citibank unit and in Hong Kong with Standard Chartered Bank, to help prime the Thai market for a new wave of consumer-credit products as it emerges from a period of political uncertainty that crested last September when a military coup ousted Prime Minister Thaksin Shinawatra.   Prior to the investment, GE Money and Bank of Ayudhya had been in a credit-card-issuing joint venture since February 2001. But of the Thai bank's customer base of more than 4.5 million people, only 14% of its loan portfolio currently comes from retail consumers. "Consumer banking is still in its infancy in this country. The opportunities are huge," Mr. Tan says.   Mr. Tan, a Singaporean, says his compulsory two-and-a-half-year stint in his homeland's armed forces as a young man also helped him see the bigger picture. "One of the things I picked up was the sense that to be successful, one has to be part of a bigger whole, which means everyone is part of a team," Mr. Tan says. It is something he is especially attuned to as a foreign chief executive working in a sector still tightly controlled by Thailand's banking authorities.   James Hookway spoke with Mr. Tan at Bank of Ayudhya's offices in Bangkok.     WSJ: When you were setting out in business, who gave you the best business advice?   Mr. Tan: Often, it's your customers who give you the best advice. As a banking professional, we speak our own language and we're proud of it when we're young. Everything we do is so micro, and we're so drilled in our own profession that we often forget what it is that the customer needs. I can remember time and time again when we suddenly stopped and said, "Hey, wait a minute, this product we just designed isn't exactly what our customers want." That's why we believe in things like customer councils, spending time with clients. Friday in this bank is customers' day, which means no meetings: all seniors go out there and meet your clients.     WSJ: What about the master's degree in business administration? Is an M.B.A. worthwhile, or is it better to learn on the job?   Mr. Tan: No preference. I still believe that people should work before they do an M.B.A., to milk the most out of it. I'm persuading my daughter, who is a law graduate, to do an M.B.A. But she has to work a few years first, in the fund-management line. Having said that, I've gone out of my way to hire people without M.B.A.s. When I was at a Citibank, I brought in a chemist. I brought in an engineer. And I brought a genetic engineer into my product-development team for derivatives. It's about mixing the molecules to form a whole.     WSJ: What piece of knowledge do you wish every prospective employee knew?   Mr. Tan: Before we go into knowledge, I think that for banking, the most important criterion is integrity. That comes before knowledge. But for knowledge, hopefully they come in with a bit of entrepreneurial drive so it makes it easier for them to understand -- conceptually -- the difference between a balance sheet and a profit-and-loss statement, so they know how to run a business.     WSJ: What's your relationship with technology? Is there any particular gadget you depend on?   Mr. Tan: I've actually stopped using a BlackBerry. I was chained to a BlackBerry for the last five years. I simply refuse to have one. My boss called my secretary and said, "Can you get him a BlackBerry?" So I told my secretary to get one for Japan, because it doesn't work here. The most critical thing in technology is the mobile phone. I use SMS [text messaging] more often than the BlackBerry because it's instantaneous. And it forces you to keep your message short and to the point.     WSJ: Have you ever had a difficult boss, and what's the best way of dealing with that situation?   Mr. Tan: I'm sure we've all come across that. But it's important to understand where they are coming from. Once you understand their rationale, it's a lot easier to deal with the situation and hopefully find a solution to it.     WSJ: What's the most difficult decision you've had to make as a manager?   Mr. Tan: I feel awkward talking about this. It was a decision on whether I should spend time with my mum in her last few days, while at the same time dealing with a retrenchment of more than 200 people in Hong Kong. My decision still haunts me today. The decision I made was that the doctors were the best people to help my mother, and I was needed by my 200 staff because they needed to be outplaced. I called my contacts in the industry and I tried to get them employed. Within three weeks we had 40% of the 200 placed out. Within six months, I think we only had two guys left without a job, and one of them had set up his own consultancy.     WSJ: How difficult is it to keep costs under control and foresee the end of a business cycle?   Mr. Tan: Everybody wants their fair share of departmental growth during a boom period, even if the managers know they're going to have to retrench. But if I'm tightening my belt [during good times] and my neighbor is not, when it comes to indiscriminate retrenchment, my guys will be hit as well. Why should they suffer during the good days and suffer during the bad days, when the neighboring department enjoys the good days? So that is the mindset we need to break. There are processes we should adopt to do that: a capacity-planning model to manage the growth of our businesses in relation to predicted future growth.   The moment that predicted future growth takes place, there are steps we need to put into place. You keep tweaking your organization chart. It's important to work on the productivity side too, so that less manpower is required. We can automate some processes and simplify, simplify, simplify. That, I think, could help prevent this ballooning, as we call it.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 01, 2007 17:30 ET (21:30 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Australia's AED Oil Boosts Recoverable Oil To 100M Bl
Story: MELBOURNE (Dow Jones)--Australia's AED Oil Ltd. (AED.AU) is expected to make a further announcement giving more details of reserves at its Timor Sea oil fields Monday or Tuesday, a person with knowledge of the situation told Dow Jones Newswires Monday.   Late Friday, AED said it believes it is likely to have 100 million barrels of recoverable oil at its Puffin and Talbot fields.   The Melbourne-based company said it was still in the process of reviewing its Timor Sea assets but that, based on the results to date, indications are the company is likely to recover more than 100 million barrels of oil subject to suitable field development.   AED has previously said it has reserves of 40 million barrels at the North East 1 field at Puffin and that initial oil in place at Puffin South West is most likely to be about 65 million barrels.     -By Alex Wilson, Dow Jones Newswires; 61-3-9671-4313; alex.wilson@dowjones.com   -Edited by Paul Dekkers     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 01, 2007 19:50 ET (23:50 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: WSJ(7/2) Young Internet Surfers Embrace `Widgets'
Story: (From THE WALL STREET JOURNAL)     By Emily Steel   A study of attitudes about online advertising shows that, not surprisingly, preteens and teenagers don't like banner ads and other interruptions from marketers. But the study found that in the right circumstances kids enjoy playing with ad-related features on their personal pages in social-networking Web sites.   The study is likely to prove useful for marketers trying to reach today's generation of children. It is likely to fuel a push by digital ad agencies to get marketers to experiment with new ways to advertise on social-networking sites such as Facebook and News Corp.'s MySpace.   In particular, the study's findings may boost advertisers' use of "widgets," which are small, easily downloaded computer programs that allow Web pages to be more sophisticated and interactive, with, say, animated graphics, videos, photo sharing, music or live chats. Media companies are rapidly recognizing the value of offering widgets to young people to make their content available online. And advertisers are starting to sponsor widget-based content as a way of spreading their marketing message or luring people to their Web sites.   Based on responses to an online survey of more than 1,200 children ages 9 to 17 and about 1,000 parents across the country, the study found that children don't want ads posted on their social-network profiles without their permission, says Samantha Skey, executive vice president of strategic marketing at Alloy Media + Marketing. Alloy based its research on a study conducted by Bethesda, Md., market researcher Grunwald Associates LLC.   "Kids have come to view [social-network profile pages] as their yearbook page. It's their collage. It's very personal," says Ms. Skey.   Children will, however, choose to post logos or promotions from advertisers on their personal pages if marketers give them an incentive, whether it is coupons and giveaways or entertaining tools, such as games, video, and animated characters. The study found that 20% of teens added content from a marketer onto their personal Web sites in the last month.   Widgets don't give advertisers any control over the type of content they'll appear alongside. But because they give consumers control, they likely fit what kids are looking for, based on the Grunwald study's findings. "The concept [of widgets] is simple. We are not going to push something in front of your screen. We are not going to annoy you. You choose what you want to engage with," says Chris Cunningham, vice president of advertising sales at Freewebs, a Silver Spring, Md.-based company that makes widgets for advertisers.   To promote the film "The Golden Compass," scheduled to hit theaters in December, New Line Cinema is running a site that lets users create a virtual "daemon" -- an animal spirit discussed in the film -- to post to their blog or MySpace pages, to add to their instant-message profile or to share with friends. Thus far, 200,000 people have created daemons and four million people interacted with them online, according to New Line Cinema, a Time Warner company.   Widgets have "so much buzz now and every advertiser wants to do a widget," says Marc Fireman, head of digital media for Reebok, which sponsored a widget six months ago. Widgets can include a link back to the advertiser's Web site, which adds to their attractiveness for marketers.   Still, popularity of widgets doesn't always translate into sales. To promote the film "Hoot," about middle-school students who take on land developers trying to build in an area where owls live, New Line Cinema last year created a program that let people download an animated pet owl to their desktops from the movie's Web site. Web users downloaded more than a million of the critters, which walk around the desktop screen, but the film was a disappointment at the box office.   "The first thing you want to do is somehow engage a consumer. Does engagement equal conversion? Not necessarily," says Gordon Paddison, executive vice president of new media marketing at New Line. "But just as with any component of marketing, media promotion, publicity and online strategy you have to find the magic sauce."   For social-networking sites, widgets have a big downside. Because of the way widgets are used -- by consumers posting the applications wherever they want -- the social networking sites can miss out on any ad revenue even when the widgets are on the site's pages. Advertisers pay only the widget maker, usually technology firms.   Indeed, MySpace says it can block widgets from its site for "commercial endeavors except those that are specifically endorsed or approved by MySpace.com." This includes carrying ads -- as well as for other reasons such as infringing copyrights.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 01, 2007 19:44 ET (23:44 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: UK OFT Decision On Crt Action Against Travel Cos Due Next Wk
Story: LONDON (Dow Jones)--U.K. government watchdog the Office of Fair Trading will announce next week whether it will take High Court action against travel firms who fail to advertise the full cost of their product up front.   A spokesman for the OFT said Sunday that a letter was sent to companies last week "expressing concern about advertising and pricing."   The letter followed a failure by travel companies to comply with an OFT ruling to ensure all advertised prices included hidden costs such as supplementary fuel or flight charges by an agreed deadline of the end of May.   The deadline has now been extended to the end of July after the OFT wasn't satisfied with the response to the ruling. A spokesman said the OFT had been hoping firms would sign up to a voluntary agreement to comply with the ruling, but that it would pursue court proceedings if necessary.   It is awaiting responses from the travel industry and will make a decision as to whether or not to pursue court action next week.   The Sunday Telegraph reported Sunday that Ryanair Holdings PLC (RYA.DB) and Thomas Cook Group PLC (TCG.LN) were among the firms who weren't yet complying with the ruling.     -By Molly Dover, Dow Jones Newswires; +44-207-842-9358; molly.dover@dowjones.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 01, 2007 06:49 ET (10:49 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Ferrovial Could Replace Metronet As Tube Operator - Newspaper
Story: LONDON (Dow Jones)--Spanish infrastructure company Ferrovial could replace the Metronet consortium as operator of the London Underground transport system, the Independent on Sunday reports citing Ferrovial chairman Rafael del Pino.   Del Pino said Ferrovial has held talks with Transport for London about taking on Metronet projects, the newspaper says. However it cites a Transport for London spokesman as saying that no talks have taken place.   Ferrovial is part of the Tube Lines consortium which is a rival to Metronet and is responsible for three London Underground tube lines.   Metronet, which is owned by Balfour Beatty PLC (BBY.LN), WS Atkins PLC (ATK.LN), Canada's Bombardier Inc. (BBD.A.T), EDF Energy (1024251.FR) and Thames Water, has been hit by rising costs and is trying to claim back GBP1 billion of additional costs from Transport for London.   A spokesman for Transport for London said it had "not had any talks with Ferrovial or Tube Lines with regards to taking over Metronet's contract."   Ferrovial was not immediately available to comment.   Newspaper Web site: http://www.independent.co.uk   -London Bureau, Dow Jones Newswires; +44 (0)20 7842 9320     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 01, 2007 08:34 ET (12:34 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: KIA Will Keep 7.2% Stake In DaimlerChrysler - Report
Story: LONDON (Dow Jones)--The Kuwait Investment Authority will maintain its 7.2% stake in German carmaker DaimlerChrysler (DCX) and believes the company has turned around and is now performing well, Reuters reports Sunday, citing KIA Executive Director Saleh al-Sagoubi.   DaimlerChrysler said in May it would sell its 80% stake in Chrysler Group to private equity firm Cerberus Capital Management, after the merger of Daimler-Benz and Chrysler didn't work out as planned, Reuters adds.   Newspaper Web site: http://www.reuters.com   -London Bureau, Dow Jones Newswires; +44 (0)20 7842 9320     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 01, 2007 10:16 ET (14:16 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.
