Headline: WSJ(7/2) Colgate's New CEO Faces Challenges, Worries
Story: (From THE WALL STREET JOURNAL)     By Ellen Byron   A new era begins today at Colgate-Palmolive Co. when Ian Cook takes over as chief executive, succeeding longtime boss Reuben Mark at a critical juncture for one of the best-known consumer-products companies in the world.   Mr. Mark, who stepped down yesterday as chief executive after 23 years, led a global expansion that made Colgate dominant in oral care throughout the world, while the overall company's sales nearly tripled to $12.2 billion. Hurt by high commodity prices, growth has lately stalled. Last year's profit was up less than 1% from a year earlier. Colgate's stock price is flat compared with the beginning of the year after soaring 34% from May 2005 to the end of 2006.   On Wall Street, some investors are worried about the company's ability to sustain growth in developing markets such as Latin America and whether it has enough new products under development. The last big breakthrough was the high-end toothpaste Colgate Total, introduced in 1997.   So far, the 55-year old Mr. Cook -- Mr. Mark's chief lieutenant for the past couple of years -- has done little to assuage their concerns. His message to Wall Street has been that he will maintain business as usual, hardly what some observers hoped to hear.   "We were disappointed," said Ali Dibadj, senior analyst at Sanford C. Bernstein & Co. "In any company there are improvements to be made, and you always want to hear those."   He noted Mr. Cook won't have the same opportunities as did Mr. Mark to generate growth by expanding overseas. "Eastern Europe is full of other competitors, and so is China and India -- Colgate doesn't have open green fields to build in anymore," Mr. Dibadj noted. The company said Mr. Cook wasn't available for an interview.   Colgate is facing a re-energized competitor in Crest toothpaste parent Procter & Gamble Co., whose purchase of Gillette in late 2005 added the Oral-B toothbrush brand to its portfolio. P&G has been spending heavily on marketing new oral-care products, such as Crest Pro-Health, aimed squarely at Total.   Mr. Cook has had other issues to grapple with. Colgate's premium pet-food products Hill's Science Diet and Hill's Prescription Diet were included in the recall of dog-and-cat foods contaminated with melamine. Last month, counterfeit versions of Colgate toothpaste tainted with the poison diethylene glycol appeared in discount stores in a handful of U.S. states. Counterfeit toothpaste has also turned up in Canada, the Associated Press reported during the weekend. Testing didn't find the chemical but did show high levels of harmful bacteria.   Despite these challenges, analysts have noted the transition has been underway for a while, helping to minimize any disruptions. Mr. Cook, who is British, has spent more than 30 years at Colgate and became chief operating officer in 2004. He was picked to succeed Mr. Mark in February of last year, over two internal rivals. Colgate's four-year restructuring plan, which has included job cuts, factory closures and an increase in marketing, is understood by many to be the work of Mr. Cook. "Ian has been warming up the car for a while," said Dave Hardie, a managing director at Herbert Mines Associates.   During the past few years, Mr. Mark, who will remain chairman for as long as 18 months, has increasingly let Mr. Cook take the spotlight in investor presentations and earnings conference calls, building the perception that he has been largely running the day-to-day operations.   Mr. Cook has a reserved, soft-spoken demeanor -- a stark contrast with the rapier wit of Mr. Mark -- though he is known for an occasional wry, deadpan remark. While Mr. Mark relished the role of corporate cheerleader, Mr. Cook's leadership style is quiet but forceful, said people who have worked with him.   That a gentler-mannered leader is replacing a loudly charismatic one follows a broader leadership trend emerging in corporate America, said Melanie Kusin, a vice chairman at executive-search firm Heidrick & Struggles, noting other well-known, mild-mannered chief executives including Mike Ullman of J.C. Penney Co., Jim McNerney of Boeing Co. and A.G. Lafley of P&G.   "Reuben is an icon, he's brilliant, and he's earned the right to have his own idiosyncricity," said Ms. Kusin. "Now we're in an era of humility."     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 01, 2007 19:47 ET (23:47 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: UK's Serious Fraud Office To Question BAE - Newspaper
Story: LONDON (Dow Jones)--The U.K.'s Serious Fraud Office is to start a second series of interviews under caution with executives from BAE Systems PLC (BA.LN) regarding allegations of corruption, the Sunday Telegraph reports citing sources close to the investigation.   The newspaper reports the allegations are of corruption outside Saudi Arabia after the SFO last year dropped its central investigation into bribery allegations surrounding weapon sales to Saudi Arabia under the Al-Yamamah government-to-government contract.   The interviews will relate to investigations into BAE's contracts in Romania, the Czech Republic, Tanzania and South Africa, the newspaper said.   A spokesman for BAE Systems told Dow Jones Newswires that the enquiry was "the same one that has been ongoing for three years," and that it was "co-operating fully and will continue to co-operate as required."   He said that employees have been questioned by the Serious Fraud Office as part of the ongoing investigation but that none have had charges brought against them.   The Serious Fraud Office was not immediately available to comment.   Newspaper Web site: http://www.telegraph.co.uk   -London Bureau, Dow Jones Newswires; +44 (0)20 7842 9320     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 01, 2007 07:13 ET (11:13 GMT)

Headline: ISS Parent RiskMetrics To Buy Forensic Accounting Firm CFRA
Story: By Kaja Whitehouse   Of DOW JONES NEWSWIRES   RiskMetrics Group, parent company of proxy advisory firm Institutional Shareholder Services, has agreed to acquire forensic accounting firm Center for Research & Analysis and will name its chief executive, Rich Leggett, as head of ISS.   Leggett will fill the gap left when former ISS CEO John Connolly stepped down in March, just a few months after ISS itself was acquired by RiskMetrics. CFRA, with just 45 employees and undisclosed revenues, is small but well regarded for providing early warning signals about companies that later have fallen into financial trouble, for instance subprime mortgage lender New Century Financial Corp. and telecommunications company Worldcom.   The deal is the latest for RiskMetrics, a New York risk management firm that was spun off from JPMorgan Chase & Co. (JPM) in 1998 and is building a stable of research and analysis services for institutional investors. Last November, RiskMetrics paid $553 million to buy ISS, the largest U.S. firm advising shareholders how to vote on corporate matters like mergers and board elections.   "Ultimately this is about doing research for institutional clients," said Ethan Berman, chief executive officer of RiskMetrics. "At the core, RiskMetrics Group is a research organization. CFRA is truly a research organization, and they are targeting same client base of institutional investors and asset owners."   RiskMetrics, with 900 employees and annual revenue of $210 million, has been in talks with investment bankers in recent months about the possibility of taking the company public.   CFRA is majority owned by private-equity firm TA Associates, which invested $60 million in the company in 2003. Berman wouldn't discuss the details of the acquisition, but a person familiar with the situation said RiskMetrics paid cash and stock worth slightly more than $65 million. Officials from TA Associates couldn't be immediately reached for comment.   Berman said RiskMetrics is thinking of further expanding with services that would help investors understand opaque investments such as hedge funds, real estate and private equity, which have been attracting greater commitments of resources from investors such as pension funds.   "I think there are areas of financial markets that can become more transparent. I think I see more and more products from us providing that transparency," said Berman.   -By Kaja Whitehouse, Dow Jones Newswires; 201-938-2243; kaja.whitehouse@dowjones.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 01, 2007 17:01 ET (21:01 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Thai PTT:Star Petroleum Refining Seen Launching IPO By End-07
Story: (This article was originally published Saturday.)     PATTAYA (Dow Jones)--Star Petroleum Refining Co., or SPRC, is expected to launch its initial public offering by the end of this year, said Prasert Bunsumpun, president of PTT PCL (PTT.TH), Thailand's oil and gas giant, adding that PTT plans to partially divest its 36% stake in the company.   "We've decided we would divest some stake in SPRC via the share offering," Prasert told reporters late Friday.   Earlier, PTT considered selling its stake to U.S.-based Chevron Corp. (CVX), which currently owns a 64% stake in SPRC, or swap its stake for a share of Chevron's upstream petroleum business overseas.   SPRC is expected to raise THB20 billion from the Stock Exchange of Thailand. Its market capitalization is estimated to be worth THB60 billion, Prasert said.   After the IPO, PTT's ownership in SPRC would decline to 25%, while that of Chevron will be cut to 45%. PTT would further divest its stake in its refinery affiliate afterwards, Prasert said.   Under its agreement with the government, SPRC is required to list on the Stock Exchange of Thailand in an exchange for obtaining a refinery license.   SPRC is operating a 150,000 barrel-per-day refinery in the country's eastern seaboard area.     -By Supunnabul Suwannakij, Dow Jones Newswires; 66 2266 0744; tu.suwannakij@dowjones.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 01, 2007 21:27 ET (01:27 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Financial News: UK's BC Partners Eyes Global Expansion
Story: By James Mawson   Of FINANCIAL NEWS     BC Partners has moved a step closer to opening offices outside of Europe after its secondary buyout of global satellites operator Intelsat for $16.4 billion last month.   People close to the U.K.-based private equity firm, which declined to comment, said it had the capability to operate globally but had not decided whether it needed a network of offices in the wake of the Intelsat deal.   Such a move would be similar to those by local peers Apax Partners, Permira and CVC Capital Partners, which in January hired Chris Stadler to head up its U.S. office.   Led by managing partner Raymond Svider, Bermuda-based Intelsat is BC's largest deal and the fifth-biggest by a single financial sponsor.   Out of the $5 billion payment for the equity value, BC is leading a group taking 76% of Intelsat but will invest less than $1 billion of its funds. Credit Suisse, which also advised Intelsat, and Banc of America Securities are arranging an equity bridge facility for part of the deal's funding.   These two banks plus Morgan Stanley are arranging $5.1 billion debt to support the secondary buyout. After $1.26 billion of existing debt is retired, Intelsat's net debt will increase by about $3.85 billion to more than $15 billion. Its debt to earnings before interest, tax, depreciation and amortization is expected to be less than nine times.   BC is understood to want to continue with the stated integration of Intelsat and PanAmSat, which are seen as having too many satellites, and maintain the agreed capital spending program set by David McGlade, the portfolio company's well-regarded chief executive.   Web site: http://www.efinancialnews.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 01, 2007 20:01 ET (00:01 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: WSJ(7/2) Altria To Launch Clove Cigarette In Indonesia
Story: (From THE WALL STREET JOURNAL)     By Tom Wright   JAKARTA -- Altria Group Inc.'s Philip Morris International will launch a clove-flavored cigarette in Indonesia under the Marlboro name as part of an effort by the U.S. tobacco company to push its premium brand in the world's fifth-largest cigarette market by volume.   In 2005, Philip Morris bought a controlling stake in PT Hanjaya Mandala Sampoerna, a firm founded in East Java in 1913 and a leading producer of sweet clove, or kretek, cigarettes that account for 90% of the Indonesian market. The deal, valued at $5.2 billion, was the largest done in Indonesia by a foreign investor.   Since the 1980s, Philip Morris has been selling traditional cigarettes, known in Indonesia as "whites," under the Marlboro brand. Despite carving out a 50% share of the small market for white cigarettes, the Marlboro name remains less known than many popular kretek brands.   Philip Morris is hoping to give a boost to the Marlboro brand through kreteks. The new product, called Marlboro Mix 9, will be unveiled tomorrow by Sampoerna.   Like many big tobacco firms, Philip Morris has been looking to diversify revenue away from core markets in the U.S., Europe and Japan. While fewer people are smoking in many Western nations, amid tighter advertising regulations on cigarettes and widespread smoking bans in public places, developing markets such as Indonesia remain a flourishing market for tobacco firms.   There are almost no restrictions on tobacco advertising in Indonesia. While ads in the media can't show people actually smoking, there are few rules banning the use of brand names in campaigns on television, print or at music concerts. There is no law setting a minimum age for smokers.   About two-thirds of adult males smoke in Indonesia according to some estimates, compared with 24% in the U.S. Indonesians last year smoked 228 billion sticks, putting the country behind China, the U.S., Russia and Japan.   Kretek, named for the crackling sound cloves make when burned, was developed in the late 19th century in Central Java. Modern kretek contain significantly higher levels of nicotine and tar than white cigarettes. The Marlboro kretek contains 1.8 milligrams of nicotine and 30 milligrams of tar; by comparison, a regular full-flavored Marlboro cigarette in the U.S. contains 1.1 milligrams of nicotine and 15 milligrams of tar.   Philip Morris says there is no evidence that kretek are more harmful than regular cigarettes, but it adds there is no such thing as a safe cigarette.   Subash Salunke, acting head of the World Health Organization's office in Indonesia, says the launch of new brands shows there is a growing market for cigarettes in a nation where the high number of smokers already is a concern. "Anything that is going to increase the number of smokers is not good for the public health," he said.   With a huge number of kretek brands available, Martin King, Sampoerna's president director, acknowledges it will be tough for the Marlboro product to carve out market share. Last year, 500 brands were launched in Indonesia, but they took only 1% of the market, according to Mr. King.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 01, 2007 19:45 ET (23:45 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Germany KfW, JR East, Others Register Bond Shelf At Japan MOF
Story: TOKYO (Dow Jones)--Kreditanstalt fur Wiederaufbau, AIG-FP Capital Funding Corp., East Japan Railway Co. (9020.TO) and others filed a shelf registration at Japan's Ministry of Finance last week, documents at the ministry showed Monday.   Germany's KfW filed shelf registration to issue up to Y500 billion of uridashi bonds. The registration is valid for two years from July 3.   AIG-FP Capital Funding filed a shelf to issue up to Y100 billion of uridashi bonds.   Uridashi are bonds issued offshore in foreign currency and sold to Japanese retail investors.   East Japan Railway registered a shelf to issue up Y750 billion of bonds over a two-year period from July 4.   Electric Power Development Co. (9513.TO) filed a shelf registration to issue up to Y400 billion of bonds over two years beginning July 3.   Also, Orix Corp. (8591.TO), Sumitomo Osaka Cement Co. (5232.TO), Sagami Railway Co. (9003.TO), Marubeni Corp. (8002.TO), Aeon Co. (8267.TO) and JFE Holdings Inc. (5411.TO) registered shelves to issue straight bonds.   There were no Samurai bond shelf registrations last week. Samurai are yen-denominated bonds issued by foreign borrowers in Japan.     Domestic and Foreign Corporate Bond Shelf Registrations (all figures are in billions of yen):       Domestic Corporate Bond Shelf Registrations  Issuer                        Limit Amount     Effective  Electric Power Development         400          July  3  East Japan Railway                 750          July  4  Orix                               700          July  5  Sumitomo Osaka Cement               40          July  6  Sagami Railway                      50          July  7  Aeon                               150          July  7  JFE Holdings                       300          July  7  Marubeni                           300          July  9        Uridashi Bond Shelf Registrations  Issuer                         Limit Amount    Effective  KfW                                500          July  3  AIG-FP Capital Funding Corp.       100          July  7     -By Hiroshi Inoue, Dow Jones Newswires; 813-5255-2995; Hiroshi.Inoue@dowjones.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 01, 2007 20:58 ET (00:58 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: German Railway Unions To Launch Strikes This Wk Over Wages
Story: BERLIN (AP)--Two German rail unions Sunday said they would launch walkouts this week in a wage dispute with the national railway operator.   Members of the GDBA and Transnet union will start the limited "warning strikes" Monday morning, concentrating on the southwest and east of Germany, Transnet deputy chairwoman Regina Rusch-Ziemba said.   Trains along the Rhine River in southwestern Germany and regional services in three eastern states were expected to be hardest hit.   The decision by the two unions comes on top of a threat by GDL, a third union that represents many of Germany's train drivers, to launch strikes this week in its own dispute with railway operator Deutsche Bahn AG.   Weekend talks between Deutsche Bahn, GDBA and Transnet produced no progress. The two unions have called for wage increases of up to 7% for some 134,000 employees.   Deutsche Bahn last week offered a more modest 2% increase next January, followed by another 2% in July 2009, and one-time extra payments of EUR300 ($400) to cover the rest of this year. The unions promptly rejected the offer.   Deutsche Bahn has argued that as many as 9,000 jobs would be endangered by an excessive wage increase.   The third union, GDL, is seeking wage increases of up to 31% for some of its members. It wants a separate deal with Deutsche Bahn, which has rejected that idea.   The German government is currently preparing plans to sell up to half of Deutsche Bahn in what would be the country's last big privatization.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 01, 2007 08:21 ET (12:21 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: WSJ(7/2) Bancroft Trusts' Lawyers Hold Key To Dow Jones
Story: (From THE WALL STREET JOURNAL)     By Matthew Karnitschnig   The Bancroft family may own a controlling stake in Dow Jones & Co., but the final decision on whether to sell the publisher of The Wall Street Journal to Rupert Murdoch could well be made by a small circle of longtime family lawyers in downtown Boston.   Lawyers from Hemenway & Barnes sit at the center of dozens of overlapping trusts that hold power over most of the Bancrofts' 64% voting stake in the company. Those lawyers occupy two of the three trustee seats on a number of key trusts, with the third held by a family member. On one of the biggest trusts, lawyers from the firm are the only trustees. And the fact that the large Bancroft clan is divided over whether to sell further deepens the firm's influence.   "The vote really resides with them," says one family member who is leaning in favor of selling the company.   Hemenway & Barnes's involvement could make approval of the deal swift if negotiators for Mr. Murdoch's News Corp. and Dow Jones agree on price. Even with 35 adult Bancroft family members still squabbling over whether to sell, less than half of the family's shares would likely be required to win approval for a deal.   That's because holders of most of the shares not in family hands -- about 36% of Dow Jones's voting power -- will likely want to take advantage of the rich premium and cash out. Approval would require a simple majority of the outstanding shares. (The Ottaway family, which controls about 7% of the shareholder vote, is expected to oppose a sale. Some shareholders will likely not vote at all, meaning that Mr. Murdoch can probably count on non-Bancrofts for 20% to 25% of the total vote.)   Hemenway & Barnes lawyers sit as trustees on funds that control a majority of the family's stake in Dow Jones. The family's remaining share is held in other trusts or by individual family members.   Last week, Dow Jones and News Corp. agreed on a framework to safeguard the editorial integrity of the Journal and the company's other publications. Price negotiations remain to be completed, and the family is expected to be polled sometime after that. (Mr. Murdoch has said that he won't go above his $60-a-share offer, a 67% premium above the stock price before the offer became public.)   Michael B. Elefante, a senior Hemenway & Barnes partner who serves as the family's lead trustee and represents them on Dow Jones's board and in the News Corp. talks, is perceived as a "seller" by some other company directors. His position on the sale will be crucial because a number of family members rely on him for guidance.   "If Elefante tells them that the agreement on editorial independence can be enforced and the principles are protected, they'll support him," said another family member who is leaning in favor of a sale.   Mr. Elefante has disputed the notion that he has already decided to sell, noting that there is a difference between listening to Mr. Murdoch's offer and supporting a sale to the media tycoon.   "There are 35 adult family members who have 35 points of view," Mr. Elefante said. "We've tried to be fair to all the family members by giving each of them all the information they need to make a good decision."   As the family's legal representative, Mr. Elefante likely would be reluctant to go against the family's wishes if a large portion of them oppose the deal. While trustees don't legally have to consult the beneficiaries of a trust before acting, ignoring their wishes might expose them to litigation. What's more, the Hemenway & Barnes trustees do not have to vote in concert. Mr. Elefante is expected to poll the family before deciding how the trusts would vote on a sale, a person close to him said.   The earliest Bancroft trusts date back to the mid-1930s. They were established for the three grandchildren of Clarence Barron, a Dow Jones correspondent in Boston who purchased the company in 1902 for $130,000.   In many cases, trusts are used to protect the property interests of minors until they reach maturity or to protect an asset from being sold. But they are also employed by wealthy families to pass businesses and other assets from one generation to the next without incurring a big tax bill. The legal instruments that hold most of the Bancrofts' shares in Dow Jones are so-called generation-skipping trusts, a structure used to protect assets from taxation.   Since Mr. Murdoch's offer, the original trusts and their offshoots are valued at more than $2 billion, according to people familiar with the situation. Over the years, the trusts have been diversified and today less than half of their assets are invested in Dow Jones. Each of the three branches holds about one-third of the supervoting Class B shares that ensure the family control of the company.   The children of the original beneficiaries, known as the "upper generation," are entitled to automatic disbursements from the trusts, which come mainly in the form of annual dividends from Dow Jones stock and other investments. Eight of the nine original members of the upper generation are still living and range in age from their 50s to their 70s.   Much of the cash disbursed to the children of the upper generation, however, is at the discretion of the trustees. In most cases, this "lower generation" is entitled to the principal after their parents die and will be free to sell the assets. It is primarily the members of the lower generation, ranging from their 20s to their 50s, who have agitated for a sale of Dow Jones. They have chafed at the disparity in the income from the trusts and other money issues.   The family fortune is divided by branch so some heirs are entitled to a much smaller piece of the pie than others. For example, Leslie Hill, who has six siblings, will inherit just about 1/42nd of the total. Her cousin Hugh Griffiths, who has no siblings, stands to inherit 1/9th.   Some in the lower generation have been pushing for changes in the way the trusts are managed, according to people familiar with the matter. One issue is the composition of the trustees. For years, Charles A. Meyer, a now-deceased Sears executive and longtime family friend, served on the main trusts. That gave the Bancrofts a family member and an ally running many of the trusts. After Mr. Meyer's retirement in the 1980s, however, he was replaced by a Hemenway & Barnes trustee or not at all. No one complained at the time.   Hemenway & Barnes, which specialized in trusts, was hired by the family in the 1940s. The only way a trustee can be removed is through the courts.   While Mr. Elefante and his colleagues have shown a willingness to take the wishes of the lower generation into account, the voice of the upper generation has carried more weight, some in the family say. Members of the upper generation sit as trustees on the key trusts with the votes to decide Dow Jones's fate.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 01, 2007 23:08 ET (03:08 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Westfarmers To Be Announced As Winner Of Coles Bid - Report
Story: DOW JONES NEWSWIRES     Westfarmers Ltd. (WES.AU) is set to be announced as the winner of the auction to by retailer Coles Group Ltd. (CGJ.AU) after the Australian conglomerate lodged a solo bid over the weekend, believed to value Coles at A$20.7 billion, The Age reported Monday.   The report said Wesfarmers boss Richard Goyder launched the bid, believed to be priced at A$17.25 a share, early Saturday after the sudden withdrawal of his private equity partners.   Coles is expected to immediately go into a trading halt Monday, pending an announcement from the board, which has spent the weekend considering bids from Wesfarmers, for the whole company, and Woolworths for parts of the business.   The report said Wesfarmers is expected to conduct a massive rights issue to fund the acquisition, which would double its size.     Newspaper web site: http://www.theage.com.au     -Wellington Bureau, Dow Jones Newswires; 64-4-471-5990; djnews.wellington@dowjones.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 01, 2007 17:30 ET (21:30 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Airbus CEO: Meaulte Plant Sale Not Finalized Yet - Report
Story: PARIS (Dow Jones)--European plane maker Airbus Chief Executive Louis Gallois told employees at Airbus' plant in Meaulte, Northern France, that he had made "no final decision" on the sale of the site, French daily Le Parisien reported Sunday.   Airbus will examine three takeover offers for the plant before the end of July, Le Parisien also reported. The offers are from plane equipment company Latecoere, an industrial partner of Airbus, as well as from U.K. engineering company GKN PLC (GKNLY) and U.S.-based Spirit AeroSystems Holdings Inc. (SPR).   Airbus is a unit of European Aeronautic Defence Space NV (5730.FR).     Newspaper Web site: http://www.leparisien.fr     -By Paris Bureau, Dow Jones Newswires; 33-1-4017 1740     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 01, 2007 09:24 ET (13:24 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: WSJ(7/2) UPDATE: Universal Music May Seek Shorter ITunes Pact
Story: (From THE WALL STREET JOURNAL)     By Ethan Smith and Nick Wingfield   Highlighting continuing tension between the music industry and Apple Inc., Vivendi SA's Universal Music Group is considering notifying the Cupertino, Calif., company that it isn't renewing a long-term contract to sell digital-music downloads through the increasingly powerful iTunes Store, according to a person familiar with the situation.   Such a move wouldn't mean Universal would remove its vast catalog -- including Eminem, 50 Cent and Sting -- from iTunes in the foreseeable future. Instead, Universal, the world's largest music company by market share, hopes to go to a short-term sales agreement rather than a contract that lasted more than a year.   Though it is unlikely to have sweeping effects immediately, such a change could give Universal more flexibility in its dealings with competitors to iTunes. For instance, it could enable the company to more easily switch gears and offer exclusive rights to parts of its catalog to other digital-download stores.   An Apple spokeswoman said the company doesn't comment on "rumors and speculation."   Universal's move comes against a backdrop of significant change in the way music is sold. Traditional music retailers have fallen by the wayside, and the major labels have seen sales declines accelerate. Meanwhile, Apple has gained greater influence in music sales, recently becoming the No. 3 seller of recorded music to the public, behind Wal-Mart Stores Inc. and Best Buy Co. Its power has made record-label executives increasingly uneasy, as it has generally refused to comply with labels' desire for flexibility on matters such as pricing.   As a result, the record labels and Apple have traded barbs with one another over the past year or so, with Apple Chief Executive Steve Jobs, for instance, calling record labels "greedy."   Practically since the launch of the iTunes store in 2003, Apple and the four major record labels have been at loggerheads over two critical issues: pricing and the lack of so-called interoperability between downloads sold by iTunes competitors and Apple's popular iPod. Apple from the start insisted on selling all downloads for 99 cents each. Record labels wanted to sell some music for more, other music for less. In an effort to break that standoff, EMI Group PLC, the No. 3 music company in the world, recently reached agreements with Apple and other digital-music sellers to sell for $1.30 downloads that are interoperable. None of EMI's competitors have followed suit.   In another illustration of the tension between Apple and the music industry, Apple doesn't currently offer wireless downloads to its new iPhone or other wireless handsets. Currently, the iPhone can store only music that is loaded by a physical connection to a computer, or "side loaded." But when asked about such a service in a recent interview, Mr. Jobs said, "There's a lot of things you can imagine down the road."   Music companies generally consider the mobile market the next frontier for their business, and are loath to let Apple dominate it that market the way it has digital downloads.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 01, 2007 23:42 ET (03:42 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: UPDATE:NYC Airport Terminal Evacuated;Suspect Package Harmless
Story: (Updates with package determined to be harmless, terminal operations resuming)     NEW YORK (AP)--Authorities found a suspicious package and evacuated AMR Corp.'s (AMR) American Airlines terminal at John F. Kennedy International Airport on Sunday, but the package proved harmless, officials said.   The package was found on the curb at 10:20 a.m., said Steve Coleman, a spokesman for the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey.   The NYPD bomb squad determined there was no danger, he said.   "It turned out to be a package containing cologne," Coleman said.   Terminal operations were back to normal within an hour. Tim Wagner, a spokesman for American Airlines, said no flights were affected.   The Port Authority, which operates JFK and LaGuardia airports in New York and Newark Liberty in New Jersey, took "a number of measures as we always do to respond to security situations immediately" after an apparent terrorist attack at the airport in Glasgow, Scotland, Coleman said Saturday.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 01, 2007 12:14 ET (16:14 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: WSJ(7/2) New Siemens CEO Has Hands Full
Story: (From THE WALL STREET JOURNAL)     By Mike Esterl in Frankfurt and David Crawford in Berlin   As a former captain of Austria's national volleyball team, Peter Loescher is used to performing under pressure.   He will need all of that cool and more in his new role as chief executive officer of Siemens AG, which is at the center of Europe's biggest corporate-corruption scandal. Today, the 49-year-old former Merck & Co. executive takes charge of Europe's largest engineering company by sales. He will have his hands full as he grapples with criminal probes that have sullied Siemens's image and raised the specter of costly fines and lawsuits.   At the same time, he must field investors' calls to accelerate a restructuring of the German conglomerate's far-flung assets to meet lofty profit targets and keep a recent share-price rally alive.   Mr. Loescher has held senior-management jobs at large companies on several continents but has never been a CEO. He is taking the helm of one of the world's most complex corporations. Siemens, based in Munich, makes goods that range from light bulbs to high-speed trains and medical scanners to wind turbines. In the fiscal year ended September, it booked 87 billion euros ($117.76 billion) in revenue.   He also represents the first outsider to head Siemens in its 160-year history and hasn't had much time to prepare. He was plucked from Merck in May to succeed Klaus Kleinfeld amid the fallout from a bribes-for-business scandal that erupted in November. Few people in Germany had heard of Mr. Loescher.   "He's a black box," says Theo Kitz, a longtime Siemens analyst at German bank Merck Finck & Co. in Munich. Siemens said Mr. Loescher was unavailable for an interview.   Mr. Kleinfeld, a 20-year Siemens veteran, said in late April he would step down as chief executive after losing the support of board members. He has denied any wrongdoing, and he hasn't been named a suspect in any of the investigations. He did face criticism that top management didn't do enough to stamp out corruption.   Siemens said in December it had identified 420 million euros in suspicious payments spanning the previous seven years. German prosecutors suspect employees set up slush funds to bribe customers, and they have arrested several former and current Siemens executives in recent months. The U.S. Justice Department and the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission also have started investigations.   Siemens is cooperating with authorities and has promised to beef up compliance. Those efforts remain a major work in progress. The company said last week that Daniel Noa is resigning as chief compliance officer after just half a year on the job.   In a statement, Chief Financial Officer Joe Kaeser thanked Mr. Noa for making "a substantial and valuable contribution" to expanding internal controls. According to a company official, however, Mr. Noa's 20 years of experience as a prosecutor of white-collar crime in Stuttgart did little to prepare him for implementing compliance procedures at a sprawling multinational company. Siemens declined to make Mr. Noa available for comment.   Another person involved in the compliance review at Siemens said the company in recent years has been very slow to replace compliance managers who failed to clamp down on alleged criminal activity. Paul Hobeck, the head of Siemens's legal department, will serve as chief compliance officer temporarily.   During his two and a half years at the helm, Mr. Kleinfeld won accolades from investors by selling unprofitable businesses such as wireless-telephone handsets and increasingly shifting the focus to three main areas: energy, health care and factory automation. Shortly before his departure, Siemens introduced ambitious profit margin targets for 2010.   Shareholders say a lot more can be done to better focus the company's portfolio and increase performance after Siemens emphasized size and market share over profits for many decades. In a recent report, the bank Dresdner Kleinwort said Siemens "remains the largest restructuring story in capital goods."   One of Mr. Loescher's immediate tasks will be deciding how to proceed with VDO, the company's electronic-auto-parts unit. Siemens announced in January that it would sell a large minority stake in the unit, which booked 10 billion euros in revenue in the most recent fiscal year, through an initial public offering. Since then, Germany's Continental AG has indicated it would like to buy the whole unit, and other buyers have expressed interest. Siemens is proceeding with the IPO plan, slated for this autumn, while listening to offers.   The new CEO is no stranger to restructurings or conglomerates. As head of corporate planning at Hoechst AG during the 1990s, he helped transform the sprawling German conglomerate into a pharmaceuticals company. He joined New Jersey drug giant Merck in May of last year after senior management stints at U.K. medical-diagnostics firm Amersham PLC and General Electric Co.   Already, he is trying to limit expectations of rapid change at Siemens. Last week, Mr. Loescher told journalists there would be no "revolution" after he takes over. The company, he said, "needs evolution."   Mr. Loescher will need to negotiate with many factions. Division heads at Siemens long have enjoyed more power than in most companies. He also will have to win the support of the nonexecutive supervisory board, which vets major decisions. Half of the board's 20 members are labor representatives. Management-labor relations soured earlier this year amid allegations that Siemens had been funding an employer-friendly labor group.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 01, 2007 19:35 ET (23:35 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: WSJ(7/2)Heard On The Street:Quiksilver May Look To Leave Slopes
Story: (From THE WALL STREET JOURNAL)     By Nicholas Casey   Having stumbled on its first trip down the ski slope, Quiksilver may be ready to quit the sport it took up just two years ago. And that could give the company's share price a nice run.   Known for its skate and surf wear, the Huntington Beach, Calif., company last month posted its first quarterly loss since 1992. The main reason: a foray into the ski business via the company's 2005 acquisition of Rossignol. The European brand, once seen as a growth opportunity, now seems to be dragging the company under the waves.   Rossignol, a mature company known for snowboards, skis and other so-called hard goods, was always viewed as an odd choice for Quiksilver, whose growth has thrived on apparel and lifestyle sportswear. What hope there was for the $305 million deal hinged on the combined company's bid to gain traction in the $47 billion-a-year outdoor market.   Then the weather changed for the worse. Last winter saw record-low snowfalls in both North America and Europe, drawing few skiers to the slopes and even fewer into stores.   Sales plummeted along with the stock price: Shares hit a 52-week low of $10.90 in March. The price has since recovered, with investors returning after solid performances by the company's apparel ventures, which include Roxy and DC shoes.   On Friday on the New York Stock Exchange, Quiksilver's shares were up 44 cents to $14.13. The stock currently trades at about 16 times estimated per-share earnings for 2008, considered in line with its peers.   But the stock's recovery isn't enough to quell analysts who believe the Rossignol brand remains a near-certain liability for investors and the company.   Quiksilver is considering whether to backtrack completely by selling Rossignol. Any sale would undoubtedly be at a loss to what the company paid, but observers say it would nonetheless boost interest in the stock by removing a cloud hanging over the company, which has a market value of about $1.7 billion.   "They are probably going to sell something, either all or part of Rossignol," says Jeff Mintz, a sportswear analyst with Wedbush Morgan Securities. While Mr. Mintz agrees that the weather was a factor in the brand's seasonal stumble, he says the company would be better to leave the ski business rather than chance another bad winter. He gives the stock a "hold" rating.   Quiksilver itself has hinted that it may be looking for a pathway off the slopes. During a conference call last month, Quiksilver Chief Executive Robert McKnight Jr. indicated that he is now considering "all the strategic possibilities" for its flagging brand.   "We're looking at every possible alternative concerning the hard goods," he said. "Everything is on the table."   Regardless, Quiksilver already has made other moves meant to curtail the damage. It has set in motion significant production cuts for Rossignol, and, even before the difficult winter, it had begun steps to close a major factory in Europe, a move set to be finished this summer. Mr. McKnight also has trimmed Rossignol's presence on the Continent significantly, bringing its offices down to just three from 17.   Rossignol isn't the only Quiksilver brand that has been getting a bad rap on Wall Street. Cleveland Golf, the company's division that produces golf clubs among other products, had a revenue slump this quarter -- it was down 6% -- and it didn't go unnoticed. On Tuesday, Quiksilver announced that it would bring its stake in the company to 100% by acquiring remaining shares of Cleveland -- what analysts say is a likely prelude to a sale.   For Rossignol, Jeff Van Sinderen, an analyst at B. Riley, advocates selling the struggling hard-goods sector of Rossignol, but maintaining licensing rights to what Quiksilver does best: hawking apparel. Revenue growth was up across the board for Quiksilver's apparel brands, with Roxy showing 20% growth and DC shoes leaping forward 60%. Analysts see similar figures possible with better weather conditions and an apparel-only Rossignol.   If Quiksilver decides to sell off all of Rossignol, "It certainly won't be what they paid for it," says Mr. Van Sinderen, who has a "buy" on the stock.   Quiksilver's equipment brands sustained a pretax loss of $50 million for the full fiscal year, ended Oct. 31. If the company were freed of Rossignol, however, retail analysts like Todd Slater of Lazard Capital Markets say they would be inclined to look on the stock more favorably. Mr. Slater already gives the stock a "buy" rating.   "The risk-reward [ratio] would improve, the earnings would improve and the stock would likely appreciate on this type of news," Mr. Slater says.   Jennifer Black, an analyst with Jennifer Black & Associates of Portland, Ore., says any sale that would decrease the firm's vulnerability would make her feel more comfortable with the stock. "The dependency of hard goods on the climate makes investors a bit nervous," she says. "There are definite concerns out there about global warming and the question of if it's going to snow." She currently gives shares a "buy" rating.   Representatives of the firm wouldn't comment on potential decisions in the Quiksilver pipeline, though executives have publicly maintained support for the Rossignol brand. What is clear, however, is that the company's latest bid to expand beyond the horizons of its sun-drenched surfer crowd may have backfired. It caught the wrong wave.   "I'm sure they'll never do something of this nature again," B. Riley's Mr. Van Sinderen says.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 01, 2007 23:00 ET (03:00 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Quinlan Team Pays GBP1 Billion For Citigroup HQ - FT
Story: DOW JONES NEWSWIRES      The European headquarters of Citigroup at Canary Wharf have been sold for GBP1 billion ($2 billion) to a consortium led by Derek Quinlan, the Irish financier, the Financial Times reported on its Web site Monday.   It is understood that Royal Bank of Scotland, which bought the building four years ago, has sold it to a joint venture of Quinlan and PropInvest, a private company run by Glenn Maud.   The sale of the 1.2m square foot Citigroup skyscraper at 25 Canada Square is the second largest single-property transaction ever seen in the UK.   The biggest was HSBC tower, also in Canary Wharf, which was bought in April by Spain's Metrovacesa for GBP1.1 billion. The Quinlan-Maud joint venture is thought to have been the underbidder on that deal.   Quinlan, a former Dublin tax inspector turned property investor, is best known for the purchase of the Savoy Group in 2004.     Newspaper Web site: http://www.ft.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 01, 2007 21:37 ET (01:37 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: WSJ(7/2) UPDATE: New Siemens CEO Has Hands Full
Story: (From THE WALL STREET JOURNAL)     By Mike Esterl in Frankfurt and David Crawford in Berlin   As a former captain of Austria's national volleyball team, Peter Loescher is used to performing under pressure.   He will need all of that cool and more in his new role as chief executive officer of Siemens AG, which is at the center of Europe's biggest corporate-corruption scandal. Today, the 49-year-old former Merck & Co. executive takes charge of Europe's largest engineering company by sales. He will have his hands full as he grapples with criminal probes that have sullied Siemens's image and raised the specter of costly fines and lawsuits.   At the same time, he must field investors' calls to accelerate a restructuring of the German conglomerate's far-flung assets to meet lofty profit targets and keep a recent share-price rally alive.   Mr. Loescher has held senior-management jobs at large companies on several continents but has never been a CEO. He is taking the helm of one of the world's most complex corporations. Siemens, based in Munich, makes goods that range from light bulbs to high-speed trains and medical scanners to wind turbines. In the fiscal year ended September, it booked 87 billion euros ($117.76 billion) in revenue.   He also represents the first outsider to head Siemens in its 160-year history and hasn't had much time to prepare. He was plucked from Merck in May to succeed Klaus Kleinfeld amid the fallout from a bribes-for-business scandal that erupted in November. Few people in Germany had heard of Mr. Loescher.   "He's a black box," says Theo Kitz, a longtime Siemens analyst at German bank Merck Finck & Co. in Munich. Siemens said Mr. Loescher was unavailable for an interview.   Mr. Kleinfeld, a 20-year Siemens veteran, said in late April he would step down as chief executive after losing the support of board members. He has denied any wrongdoing, and he hasn't been named a suspect in any of the investigations. He did face criticism that top management didn't do enough to stamp out corruption.   Siemens said in December it had identified 420 million euros in suspicious payments spanning the previous seven years. German prosecutors suspect employees set up slush funds to bribe customers, and they have arrested several former and current Siemens executives in recent months. The U.S. Justice Department and the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission also have started investigations.   Siemens is cooperating with authorities and has promised to beef up compliance. Those efforts remain a major work in progress. The company said last week that Daniel Noa is resigning as chief compliance officer after just half a year on the job.   In a statement, Chief Financial Officer Joe Kaeser thanked Mr. Noa for making "a substantial and valuable contribution" to expanding internal controls. According to a company official, however, Mr. Noa's 20 years of experience as a prosecutor of white-collar crime in Stuttgart did little to prepare him for implementing compliance procedures at a sprawling multinational company. Siemens declined to make Mr. Noa available for comment.   Another person involved in the compliance review at Siemens said the company has been very slow to replace compliance managers who held compliance responsibilities in recent years, when the alleged criminal activity took place. Paul Hobeck, the head of Siemens's legal department, will serve as chief compliance officer temporarily.   During his 2 1/2 years at the helm, Mr. Kleinfeld won accolades from investors by selling unprofitable businesses such as wireless-telephone handsets and increasingly shifting the focus to three main areas: energy, health care and factory automation. Shortly before his departure, Siemens introduced ambitious profit margin targets for 2010.   Shareholders say a lot more can be done to better focus the company's portfolio and increase performance after Siemens emphasized size and market share over profits for many decades. In a recent report, the bank Dresdner Kleinwort said Siemens "remains the largest restructuring story in capital goods."   One of Mr. Loescher's immediate tasks will be deciding how to proceed with VDO, the company's electronic-auto-parts unit. Siemens announced in January that it would sell a large minority stake in the unit, which booked 10 billion euros in revenue in the most recent fiscal year, through an initial public offering. Since then, Germany's Continental AG has indicated it would like to buy the whole unit, and other buyers have expressed interest. Siemens is proceeding with the IPO plan, slated for this autumn, while listening to offers.   The new CEO is no stranger to restructurings or conglomerates. As head of corporate planning at Hoechst AG during the 1990s, he helped transform the sprawling German conglomerate into a pharmaceuticals company. He joined New Jersey drug giant Merck in May of last year after senior management stints at U.K. medical-diagnostics firm Amersham PLC and General Electric Co.   Already, he is trying to limit expectations of rapid change at Siemens. Last week, Mr. Loescher told journalists there would be no "revolution" after he takes over. The company, he said, "needs evolution."   Mr. Loescher will need to negotiate with many factions. Division heads at Siemens long have enjoyed more power than in most companies. He also will have to win the support of the nonexecutive supervisory board, which vets major decisions. Half of the board's 20 members are labor representatives. Management-labor relations soured earlier this year amid allegations that Siemens had been funding an employer-friendly labor group.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 01, 2007 22:43 ET (02:43 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: WSJA(7/2)Heard In India:Vedanta, Sterlite Pin Hopes On Metals
Story: (From THE WALL STREET JOURNAL ASIA)     By Jackie Range   New Delhi -- SHARES OF Vedanta Resources and its majority-owned unit, Sterlite Industries (India), appeal to some investors as offering exposure to India's rapid growth in a sector that's booming globally: mining and metals.   After solid price gains, the question of whether investors should load up on the stock now depends largely on their view of the Agarwal family. Entrepreneur Anil Agarwal and his family own 54% of Vedanta, a metals and mining company that's listed on the London Stock Exchange and has the bulk of its assets in India.   Vedanta owns a majority of Sterlite, India's biggest nonferrous metals and mining company by sales. Mr. Agarwal is Vedanta's executive chairman and Sterlite's nonexecutive chairman. One brother, Navin, is deputy executive chairman of Vedanta and executive vice chairman of Sterlite.   It's common for large Indian companies to be family-controlled. Technology giant Wipro is 81%-owned by Chairman Azim Premji and his family. Another metal company, Essar Steel, is 87%-owned by the Ruia family.   As long as the interests of a family and of other shareholders align, there's usually little conflict. In the case of the Vedanta group, many shareholders say Mr. Agarwal and family have delivered superb returns. The companies have also delivered surprises that not everyone welcomed.   When Vedanta listed in London in December 2003, it said one of its aims was to consolidate its group structure by increasing direct ownership in subsidiaries. Yet Sterlite in June listed $2 billion of American depositary shares on the New York Stock Exchange -- doing just the opposite and reducing direct ownership. When Vedanta unveiled the Sterlite fund-raising plan last November, Vedanta's share price dropped 7%, though it later recovered. Vedanta's pre-issue holding in Sterlite has dropped to slightly more than 60% from 75.9%.   "It's certainly a change of strategy" said Charles Kernot, a mining analyst at Seymour Pierce, a London-based investment bank and broker that hasn't done work for Vedanta or Sterlite and doesn't own shares in either.   A Vedanta spokesman said in an email that the company has delivered on its goal of consolidating the group structure, such as through an earlier Sterlite rights issue, and that consolidation remains a main element of its strategy. Vedanta bought shares in an earlier Sterlite rights issue, thereby increasing its holding.   Moreover, a Vedanta spokeswoman added, the Sterlite ADS was needed in order for the company to exercise an option to increase its shareholding in Indian zinc producer Hindustan Zinc and move into commercial power-generation. Both that option and the power business run under Sterlite, not Vedanta.   "These investments will be value and earnings accretive to Sterlite shareholders and by extension Vedanta shareholders," she said. The spokeswoman added that Vedanta met major shareholders to explain the ADS rationale, and many "decided to participate." The Agarwal family's holding company, Volcan Investments, doesn't own any Sterlite shares, so "consequently the interests of the Agarwal family and public shareholders are totally aligned through their ownership of Vedanta," she noted.   "You want to be sure that the family's interests are in line with the other shareholders," said Graham Birch, head of the natural resources team in London at BlackRock MLIM, a New York investment-management company. BlackRock owns Vedanta shares and the Sterlite ADS but Mr. Birch declined to say how many. He added that "on the whole, we've seen reasonable alignment of interest" with the family and their experiences "have been good ones."   "We like the entrepreneurial character of this management team and that's why we backed the Sterlite ADS issue," Mr. Birch added. He said his fund could buy Sterlite's New York issue, so "our economic interest was unaffected." For those that couldn't buy, such as funds that aren't permitted to invest in stocks outside the U.K., "you might feel that your interest had been slightly diluted," he said.   Shares of Vedanta closed Friday at 1,615 pence ($32.42) and have gained 32% so far in 2007. Since a year ago, Sterlite's shares have risen 44%, closing Friday at 585.10 rupees ($14.44). The Sterlite ADS, meanwhile, hasn't soared. Priced at $13.44, it ended its first day of trading at $14.70 and closed Friday at $14.67.   Both companies have prospered from the mining and metals boom fueled by growth in Asia's large economies. Vedanta's revenue rose 76% to $6.5 billion in the year ended March 31; Sterlite's rose 96% to 244 billion rupees.   "We feel there's a lot of value left in the company," says Vishal Chandak, analyst at Emkay Share and Stock Brokers in Mumbai. He likes its plans for power production and management's record of reinvesting in the business. Mr. Chandak has a "buy" on Sterlite's shares and a 12-month target price of 670 rupees. Emkay has no investment-banking relationship with the company.   Not every opportunity Mr. Agarwal pursues has done well. Last year, Vedanta bought all of Sterlite Gold, a Toronto-listed company in which the Agarwals had a 55% stake. It hasn't produced gold since earlier this year after its mining operations were suspended in a disagreement with the Armenian government. Vedanta is now considering now selling the business.   "This was not an ideal acquisition for the group," Deutsche Bank analysts said in a note May 15. Still, Deutsche rates Vedanta shares a "buy," saying after a recent iron ore deal "Vedanta is emerging as a true global player, against the backdrop of a strong commodity price environment." Efforts to confirm if Deutsche Bank has an investment banking relationship with Vedanta or Sterlite, or own shares in either, weren't immediately successful.   Mr. Agarwal, 55 years old, has said he wants to turn Vedanta into the CVRD of India -- a reference to Brazilian mining company Companhia Vale do Rio Doce, which produces various commodities and is the world's biggest iron-ore producer. He also plans to move into nuclear power when the Indian government clarifies its policy on commercial production. In April, Vedanta bought 51% of Indian iron-ore outfit Sesa Goa for $981 million, adding to a suite that includes copper, aluminum and zinc.   Fans of the shares say expansion makes sense. Both Vedanta and Sterlite have low mining costs, analysts say. Amid a boom, most mining companies are grappling with rising costs, as they compete for supplies, such as tires for trucks. Equally, Vedanta and Sterlite have a strong record of delivering large construction projects -- such as smelters -- on time and on budget.   "There's very, very few investment vehicles that we can use to get exposure to India," said Mr. Birch, adding "We like the management of both companies, which is obviously very similar."   ---   Vibhuti Agarwal contributed to this article.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 01, 2007 17:30 ET (21:30 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Suspicious Package Forces Evacuation Of NYC Airport Terminal
Story: NEW YORK (AP)--Authorities found a suspicious package and evacuated AMR Corp.'s (AMR) American Airlines terminal at John F. Kennedy International Airport on Sunday, officials said.   The package was found on the curb at 10:20 a.m., said Steve Coleman, a spokesman for the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey. The NYPD bomb squad was en route, he said.   It was not immediately clear how many passengers were evacuated or if any flights were affected.   The Port Authority, which operates JFK and LaGuardia airports in New York and Newark Liberty in New Jersey, took "a number of measures as we always do to respond to security situations immediately" after an apparent terrorist attack at the airport in Glasgow, Scotland, Coleman said Saturday.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 01, 2007 11:39 ET (15:39 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: WSJ(7/2) Stock Market Quarterly Review: Blackstone Leads Robust IPOs
Story: (From THE WALL STREET JOURNAL)     By Yvonne Ball   Blackstone Group's $4.75 billion initial public offering highlighted a strong second quarter in the new-issues market as the number of deals and money raised exceeded last year's totals.   The private-equity giant's stock-market debut June 22 and last week's seven offerings took the number of companies that went public on U.S. exchanges in the second quarter, excluding real-estate investment trusts and special-purpose acquisition companies, to 56, according to data tracker Dealogic. That is a 22% jump from last year's second quarter.   It increases the number of IPOs this year to 104, up from 89 in the first six months of 2006.   Blackstone's IPO was among the largest on Wall Street and one of the most talked about, in part because of the eye-popping payday it delivered to its executives. The offering, which was increased from $4.1 billion by the purchase of additional shares known as overallotments, lifted the money raised from second-quarter IPOs to $16.2 billion, more than the $11.2 billion raised in the second quarter last year. Blackstone co-founder and Chief Executive Stephen Schwarzman's stake in the New York company was valued at more than $8.7 billion based on the stock's close on its first day of trading.   The third quarter could be just as lucrative. "I would say the second half of this year is looking very good. I think it is going to be at least as strong as the first half assuming overall market conditions hold up," said David Topper, co-head of equity capital markets at J.P. Morgan Chase & Co.'s securities unit.   Some 84 companies have filed paperwork with the Securities and Exchange Commission to go public in the third quarter and beyond. Together, they plan to raise about $18.5 billion.   MF Global Ltd., a brokerage-firm spinoff of London hedge-fund manager Man Group PLC, could raise as much as $4.18 billion through its public offering, expected to begin trading on the New York Stock Exchange this month.   The IPO market wasn't only strong in the U.S. World-wide, 340 deals raised $79.5 billion in the second quarter, up 28% from the 266 deals that raised $64.3 billion a year earlier. Financial stocks dominated the market with 55 deals and they raised the most money from investors, bringing in $27.4 billion.   The finance sector, thanks largely to Blackstone, also led the pack in terms of money raised in the U.S. Some $5.6 billion was raised by seven financial IPOs in the second quarter, up from last year's four such deals that raised $3 billion.   The sector will remain in the headlines in the third quarter as MF Global prepares to go public. Speculation is likely to continue about whether another private-equity behemoth, Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Co., will go public, which it was reported to be considering last month.   Although the finance sector offered the biggest deals in terms of dollars raised, in terms of sheer numbers it was overshadowed by a resurgent technology sector.   Investors snapped up opportunities in high-expansion stocks that generally boasted solid business models, unlike many of the companies that went public during the dot-com boom in the late 1990s.   This year, 27 technology stocks have gone public, raising a total of $4.3 billion. In the second quarter, 15 tech companies raised $2.8 billion.   The sector accounts for some of the best-performing IPOs this year, including Sunnyvale, Calif., optical-communications equipment maker Infinera Corp., which surged nearly 52% on its first day of trading on the Nasdaq Stock Market in June. Data Domain Inc., a data-storage company in Santa Clara, Calif., gained 66% on its first day of trading. Limelight Networks Inc., of Tempe, Ariz., which went public the following day, surged 48%.   New York hedge fund Fortress Investment Group LLC remains the best-performing IPO this year after surging 68% on its first day of trading in February.   "Technology volume is definitely more robust than it has been in quite some time and it will continue to grow, especially if investors continue to see strong returns on technology IPOs as they did [in the] second quarter of 2007," said Suzanne Skipper, managing director and head of equity capital markets at Merriman Curhan Ford & Co., a San Francisco investment bank.   The 15 technology stocks that went public in the past three months returned on average 22% after their first day of trading, above the 10% first-day return from all IPOs in the latest quarter and 7% in the second quarter of 2006.   Not far behind technology in terms of activity was health care. In the second quarter 14 biotechnology, pharmaceutical or medical-device companies have gone public. The typically smaller-size offerings mean the total amount raised was fairly low, at a total of $1.6 billion. The first-day returns also were low, averaging 3.6%.   The subdued performances aren't surprising. Many health-care companies go public before they receive regulatory approval for their products and thus don't yet generate revenue or turn a profit.   "The prevalence of health-care and technology offerings . . . is a sign of an increasingly healthy IPO market," said David DiPietro, president of specialty investment bank Signal Hill in Baltimore. "To venture capitalists and entrepreneurs in small-cap land with a very good story, it shows that at least for now, there appears to be a nice window for going public."   There also have been more public offerings from special-purpose acquisition companies, or SPACs. Also known as "blank check" companies, they are empty shells that promise to buy a business with the proceeds from their IPOs.   So far this year, 34 SPACs have gone public compared with 23 at this time last year.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 01, 2007 21:00 ET (01:00 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Financial News: Banks Shun National Grid Loan Deal
Story: By James Mawson   Of FINANCIAL NEWS     The debt financing for Australian bank Macquarie's leveraged buyout of U.K. mobile phone mast owner National Grid Wireless has run into difficulties, reflecting nervousness over financial sponsor deals and the credit markets.   There was strong institutional interest but weak bank demand for a GBP3.4 billion (EUR5.1 billion) loan backing the merger of Wireless with Arqiva, Macquarie's broadcast towers business, which was acquired from the BBC in 2005, according to sources.   Macquarie, which declined to comment, had reportedly expected to close the financing two weeks ago. One person familiar with the situation said: "The institutional tranche was 300% oversubscribed but the banking facility is taking longer."   Another person said the market had split between those buying into the combined broadcast business as a utility and those more skeptical about its risks.   Macquarie's struggle comes after the canceled $650 million (EUR483 million) bond issue for U.S. Foodservice's leveraged buyout from Dutch retailer Ahold last week.   Other bond deals were halted, including that of Misc, a tanker owner, which shelved a $750 million issue. Arcelor Mittal (MT), the world's largest steelmaker, postponed its EUR1.5 billion Eurobond sale as hedge fund losses in the U.S. subprime mortgage sector heightened volatility in the credit markets.   There are concerns the sharp fall in prices for subprime mortgages, affecting collateralized debt obligations and the hedge funds that own them, could spill over to the high-yield market.   Mehernosh Engineer, senior credit strategist at BNP Paribas, said: "There is a real indication that there is a flight to safety. Quite a few new issue deals were pulled in Europe, the U.S. and Asia and those are big names with nothing to do with subprime."   A third debt market participant said: "There is a wobble with some repricing of debt terms." A fourth observer added debt-arranging banks were struggling to syndicate other deals while sales of quasi-equity securities, such as payment-in-kind notes, were ailing.     Web site: http://www.efinancialnews.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 01, 2007 20:01 ET (00:01 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: UPDATE: Australia's Macquarie Buys US Global Towers
Story: (Adds background, Blackstone comment)       By Lyndal McFarland     Of DOW JONES NEWSWIRES     SYDNEY (Dow Jones)--Australia's Macquarie Communications Infrastructure Group (MCG.AU) said Monday it has agreed to acquire U.S.-based Global Tower Partners from Blackstone Group (BGP.XX) as part of a Macquarie Bank Ltd. (MBL.AU) consortium.   In a statement, Sydney-based Macquarie Communications said the acquisition has an enterprise value of US$1.43 billion.   "Through this acquisition Macquarie Communications has gained a timely position in a familiar industry in the attractive U.S. market," Macquarie Communications chief executive Scott Davies said.   Macquarie Communications will take a 28.7% stake in GTP, while partner Macquarie Infrastructure Partners will take 56.2%. The remaining equity will be held by two other unlisted Macquarie Bank funds and by GTP management.   Macquarie said GTP owns 2500 towers and 4600 rooftop sites for wireless communications in the U.S. and Puerto Rico.   The significant majority of GTP's revenue base is derived from long-term contracts with major wireless operators, including AT&T, Sprint-Nextel, T-Mobile and Verizon Wireless.   "It has been a privilege to be partnered with...the GTP management team as they built a world class tower company, more than quintupling revenues, increasing earnings sixfold and adding new employees and offices during our investment period," Blackstone senior managing director Ben Jenkins said in a separate statement.   "This transaction demonstrates the significant value that has been created," he said.   The acquisition will be funded by a combination of US$906 million equity, existing GTP debt of US$521 million and subordinated debt of US$110 million.   Macquarie Communications investment totals approximately A$444 million, including a contribution of subordinated debt of A$115 million and transaction costs of approximately A$18 million.   Macquarie Communications was placed in a trading halt Monday ahead of a bookbuild of exchangeable bonds in connection to the acquisition, which is subject to U.S. regulatory approval.       -By Lyndal McFarland, Dow Jones Newswires; 61-2-8235-2957; lyndal.mcfarland@dowjones.com     -Edited by Graham Morgan     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 01, 2007 21:07 ET (01:07 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Singapore ComforDelGro Forms Taxi Joint Venture In China
Story: SINGAPORE (Dow Jones)-- Singapore transport company ComfortDelGro Corp. Ltd. (C52.SG) said Monday it has formed a joint venture with a Chinese firm to operate taxis in Nanjing city in China.   In a statement, Comfort said it is investing CNY120 million in cash and will take a 70% stake in the venture.   Its venture partner, Nanjing Bulk Lifting and Transportation Group Co. Ltd., will take a 30% stake, contributing taxis, taxi licenses and other operating assets into the venture.   With the new venture, Comfort said it will have investments in 13 cities in China.   The investment is not expected to have any material impact on the net tangible assets backing per share and earnings per share of Comfort for its fiscal year ending December 31.   -By Vladimir Guevarra, Dow Jones Newswires; +65 6415 4155; vladimir.guevarra@dowjones.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 01, 2007 19:36 ET (23:36 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: : Tenet Acquires Coastal Carolina Medical Center
Story: DALLAS--(BUSINESS WIRE)--July 01, 2007--   Tenet Healthcare Corporation (NYSE: THC) announced today that a subsidiary has completed the purchase of Coastal Carolina Medical Center, a 41-bed acute care hospital located in Hardeeville, S.C., from LifePoint Hospitals Inc. (NYSE: LPNT). The approximate purchase price is $35 million and is subject to normal post-closing adjustments.     Coastal Carolina Medical Center serves a vibrant market with a growing population of younger retirees in Jasper County. The area is poised to add more than 100,000 residents in the next 20 years, with much of the growth projected around Hardeeville. The hospital is located 27 miles from Tenet's Hilton Head Regional Medical Center. The company intends to continue operating Coastal Carolina Medical Center as a full-service community hospital and will seek to enhance services to meet the community's needs, in coordination with the nearby Hilton Head facility.     "Tenet's growth strategy includes leveraging the strength of our current hospitals to grow in key markets where we already operate," said Trevor Fetter, Tenet's president and chief executive officer. "This acquisition - our first in five years of an acute care general hospital -fits that strategy perfectly. We have served the coastal areas of South Carolina for many years both at Hilton Head Regional Medical Center and at East Cooper Regional Medical Center near Charleston - two of our most successful hospitals. We strongly believe that Coastal Carolina Medical Center will benefit significantly by partnering with Hilton Head and Tenet to serve one of the nation's most dynamic, rapidly growing communities."     Coastal Carolina Medical Center will become a part of Tenet's Southern States Region and will maintain a local management team. The hospital's chief executive officer will report to Elizabeth Lamkin, the chief executive officer at Hilton Head Regional Medical Center. Coastal Carolina Medical Center will continue to operate under its current name. This strategy builds on the hospital's existing brand equity and will streamline Tenet's operational efficiency. Through this integrated approach Tenet can provide comprehensive, cost-effective health care services to the Lowcountry, as that area is known.     Stephen L. Newman, M.D., Tenet's chief operating officer, said, "We are strategically applying our capital to build upon our current market success in a highly desirable area, and will grow Coastal Carolina's services by linking it with our other nearby operations. Because we know the Lowcountry area of South Carolina so well and have served it for many years, we will hit the ground running with strategies to expand and enhance services at Coastal Carolina Medical Center."     Coastal Carolina Medical Center opened in November 2004. The hospital was acquired by LifePoint in April 2005. It was the only hospital that LifePoint operated in South Carolina.     As part of the agreement, Tenet has committed to offer employment to substantially all current employees in good standing who meet its condition of employment.     Tenet Healthcare Corporation, through its subsidiaries, owns and operates acute care hospitals and related health care services. Tenet's hospitals aim to provide the best possible care to every patient who comes through their doors, with a clear focus on quality and service. Tenet can be found on the World Wide Web at www.tenethealth.com.     Some of the statements in this release may constitute forward-looking statements. Such statements are based on our current expectations and could be affected by numerous factors and are subject to various risks and uncertainties discussed in our filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission, including our annual report on Form 10-K for the year ended Dec. 31, 2006, our quarterly reports on Form 10-Q and periodic reports on Form 8-K. Do not rely on any forward-looking statement, as we cannot predict or control many of the factors that ultimately may affect our ability to achieve the results estimated. We make no promise to update any forward-looking statement, whether as a result of changes in underlying factors, new information, future events or otherwise.        CONTACT: Media:               Steven Campanini, 469-893-6321               steven.campanini@tenethealth.com               or               Investors:               Thomas Rice, 469-893-2522               thomas.rice@tenethealth.com        SOURCE: Tenet Healthcare Corporation  Copyright Business Wire 2007     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 01, 2007 12:00 ET (16:00 GMT)

Headline: Deutsche Telekom Mulls Selling Directory Inquiries - Report
Story: FRANKFURT (Dow Jones)--Deutsche Telekom AG (DT) is considering selling its directory inquiries unit 11833, German weekly magazine WirtschaftsWoche reports in an article to be published Monday, citing people on the company's management board.   "We're examining all strategic options," the magazine quotes the people as saying.   The company is expecting "attractive offers" from some 20 interested parties, mostly domestic and foreign call center operators, WirtschaftsWoche reports.   Deutsche Telekom is expecting to generate proceeds in the "middle triple-digit millions of euros area," the magazine adds.   The company's directory inquiries unit generates around EUR200 million in sales annually, and has a market share of more than 60%, the report says.     Magazine Web site: http://www.wiwo.de     -Frankfurt Bureau, Dow Jones Newswires; 49-69-29725-500.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 01, 2007 08:01 ET (12:01 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: DaimlerChrysler Plans To End A-Class Model Production -Report
Story: FRANKFURT (Dow Jones)--DaimlerChrysler AG's (DCX) Mercedes Benz unit intends to discontinue production of its A-class model from 2011, weekly magazine WirtschaftsWoche reports ahead of publication Monday, citing information from within the company.   The magazine reports that Chief Executive Dieter Zetsche plans to phase out the A-class and B-class models and develop a new model that is based on the slightly larger B-class.   A spokesman for DaimlerChrysler declined to comment on the company's future product portfolio. He added that the A- and B-class models are firm components of the Mercedes Benz product portfolio.     Magazine Web site: http://www.focus.de     -Frankfurt Bureau, Dow Jones Newswires; 49-69-29725-500.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 01, 2007 08:50 ET (12:50 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.
