Headline: WSJ(7/2) Universal Music May Seek Shorter ITunes Contract
Story: (From THE WALL STREET JOURNAL)     By Ethan Smith and Nick Wingfield   Highlighting continuing tension between the music industry and Apple Inc., Vivendi SA's Universal Music Group is considering notifying the Cupertino, Calif., company that it isn't renewing a long-term contract to sell digital music downloads through the increasingly powerful iTunes Store, according to a person familiar with the situation.   The move doesn't mean Universal will remove its vast catalog, which includes Eminem, 50 Cent and Sting, from iTunes in the foreseeable future. Universal, which is the world's largest music company by market share, hopes to go to a short-term sales agreement instead of one that lasts a year or more.   Although it is unlikely to have sweeping effects immediately, the change could give Universal more flexibility in its dealings with competitors to iTunes. For instance, it could enable the company to offer other digital-download stores exclusive rights to parts of its catalog.   Universal's move comes against a backdrop of dramatic change in the way music is sold. As traditional music retailers have fallen by the wayside, Apple has gained an outsize influence in music sales, recently becoming the No. 3 seller of recorded music to the public, behind Wal-Mart Stores Inc. and Best Buy Co. Its power has made record-label executives increasingly uneasy, as it has generally refused to comply with labels' desires for flexibility on matters such as pricing.   As a result, the record labels and Apple have traded barbs over the past year or so; Apple Chief Executive Steve Jobs has called record labels "greedy."   An Apple spokeswoman said the company doesn't comment on "rumors and speculation."     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 01, 2007 22:52 ET (02:52 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: TPG, Warburg Pincus To Buy New Look For GBP1.7B - Newspaper
Story: LONDON (Dow Jones)--Private equity firms Texas Pacific Group and Warburg Pincus are frontrunners to buy U.K. fashion retailer New Look for GBP1.7 billion, the Mail on Sunday reports without citing sources.   The deal could be announced next week, although Merrill Lynch, which is advising on the sale, is still trying to attract higher bidders, the newspaper adds.   New Look, Texas Pacific Group and Warburg Pincus were not immediately available to comment.   Newspaper Web site: http://www.mailonsunday.co.uk   -London Bureau, Dow Jones Newswires; +44 (0)20 7842 9320     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 01, 2007 09:04 ET (13:04 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Qatari Sainsbury Stake Is Not About Property - Newspaper
Story: LONDON (Dow Jones)--Paul Taylor, adviser to the Qatari-linked investment fund which has built up a 25% stake in J Sainsbury PLC (SBRY.LN) said the investment is "not about real estate" but is about "investing in good, solid fundamental U.K. businesses," according to an interview in the Sunday Times.   Taylor used to work for property entrepreneur Robert Tchenguiz, who has a 10% stake in Sainsbury, and has called for Sainsbury to split off its extensive property portfolio, which is valued at around GBP8.6 billion.   Taylor said in the Sunday Times interview that Delta Two, the Qatari fund he advises, is a long-term investor.   Newspaper Web site: http://www.timesonline.co.uk   -London Bureau, Dow Jones Newswires; +44 (0)20 7842 9320     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 01, 2007 09:02 ET (13:02 GMT)

Headline: INTERVIEW: German Telecom Co Versatel Plans Takeovers In 07
Story: By Stefan Paul Mechnig   Of Dow Jones Newswires     DUESSELDORF (Dow Jones)--Versatel AG (VTW.XE), Germany's third-largest fixed-line telephony company, still plans to complete takeovers of competitors as early as 2007.   "We'd be disappointed should we not manage to conclude at least one transaction in 2007," Chief Executive Peer Knauer told Dow Jones Newswires in an interview.   Knauer said that the company has improved its financial flexibility by going public in April and issuing a bond last month. The cash generated from this will allow the Duesseldorf-based company to spend up to EUR500 million on acquisitions, he added.   Versatel is monitoring the market for telephone companies that own network infrastructure, but may also take over smaller competitors to increase its customer base, Knauer said in the interview.   Knauer also didn't rule out taking over parts of freenet.de AG (FRN.XE) should the opportunity arise.   Freenet shareholders Drillisch AG (DRI.XE) and financial investor Florian Homm have argued the company should sell its internet operations to create more value.   Freenet recently merged with mobile phone network operator Mobilcom.   The CEO also confirmed the company's financial targets for 2007, saying it still expects sales to come in at between EUR740 million and EUR760 million, compared with EUR666 million a year earlier. Versatel's adjusted operating earnings margin is expected to be slightly lower in 2007, at 30% compared with 31.8% in 2006.     Company Web site: http://www.versatel.de     -By Stefan Paul Mechnig, Dow Jones Newswires; +49 211 138 72 13; tmt.dedowjones.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 01, 2007 11:22 ET (15:22 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: WSJ(7/2) BCE $32.6B Buyout Reinforces Private-Equity Trend
Story: (From THE WALL STREET JOURNAL)     By Sarah Childress and Dennis K. Berman   The $32.6 billion buyout of Canadian telecommunications operator BCE Inc. -- the largest in the country's history and the telecom industry globally -- marks increasing interest from private-equity buyers in national telecom companies burdened by debt and competition from start-ups.   It also marks the latest big private-equity deal as buyout firms seek larger and larger targets, adding to their risk.   BCE said it agreed to be acquired by the investment arm of Ontario Teachers' Pension Plan, Providence Equity Partners Inc. and Madison Dearborn Partners for $32.6 billion. The deal also includes an additional $15.9 billion in debt, preferred equity and minority interests, for a buyout package valued at an overall $48.5 billion.   In recent years, private-equity firms have pursued national telecom companies like BCE, which are often threatened by more-nimble rivals. Providence, for example, has been part of groups that acquired two national telecom companies in recent years: Ireland's Eircom in 2001 and the Danish company TDC in 2006.   This deal is another in a crescendo of buyouts in which private-equity companies take on increasingly greater risks, looking for profits in a matter of months, not years. "The plan in private equity is to go after bigger and bigger deals, and this is yet another level," says Shahid Khan, a partner at Interactive Broadband Consulting Group.   "The economics of the business are just amazing, but the timeline of the cycle is shrinking," Mr. Khan said. He added: "I don't know how long this model is sustainable."   Under the deal, the buyout group will purchase each of BCE's shares for 42.75 Canadian dollars, or US$40.12, a 40% premium over the average first-quarter share price before it rose in late March amid rumors of a buyout. Friday, BCE's shares were priced at $37.79 in 4 p.m. composite trading on the New York Stock Exchange.   The deal still must be approved by BCE's shareholders and cleared by Canada's Competition Bureau. Ontario Teachers' Pension Plan is already BCE's largest shareholder.   With a market capitalization of $30 billion, BCE dominates the telecom market in Eastern Canada, selling fixed-line, wireless, high-speed Internet and video services. The company's stock had stagnated in recent years as the company struggled to stay competitive. BCE had trouble signing up subscribers to its Bell Wireless cellphone unit and its land-line division lost access lines to cheaper cable providers. Meanwhile, smaller rivals Telus Corp. and Rogers Communications Inc. both saw overall growth.   Providence Equity Partners began looking seriously at BCE this spring, according to a person familiar with the matter. In March, Providence's chief executive, Jonathan Nelson, spoke with Michael Sabia, the head of BCE, about a potential buyout. Mr. Sabia said he wasn't interested, according to a person familiar with the matter. But shortly afterward, Ontario Teachers' Pension Plan began pushing for a sale. "That just kicked things off," this person said.   Despite interest from several private-equity groups, BCE was widely expected to be taken over by Telus, its leading rival. But last week, Telus decided not to submit a bid, citing "inadequacies" in the bidding process. It still could enter a friendly or hostile bid. "For traditional companies like Telus, it's very difficult for them to go out and compete with private-equity shops," says Mr. Khan, of Interactive Broadband. Telus would have to expend much more capital and risk stock fluctuations, he says, and likely wouldn't return to the table unless it has an unbeatable deal.   A Telus spokesman declined to comment yesterday.   Telus's decision left three major bidders to submit plans to BCE's board Friday. Cerberus Capital Management and the Hospitals of Ontario Pension Plan submitted a bid, as well as the Canadian Pension Plan Investment Board and buyout firm Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Co., despite a last-minute pullout of partners Caisse de Depot et Placement du Quebec in Montreal and Onex Corp. All are major Canadian funds partnered with U.S. private-equity firms because, according to federal law, foreign companies can own no more than 46.67% of telecom providers.   Yesterday, the Cerberus group was still considering its options, a person familiar with the matter said. This person said the group was frustrated with what it felt was an expedited bidding process. The group had presented a plan that would have offered $44 a share -- $38 in cash with with an additional guarantee of $6 if BCE's price fell below $44.   Had BCE's advisers worked with Cerberus in an effort to improve that group's proposal, this person said, "it could have made their shareholders an extra billion dollars." A BCE spokesman couldn't be reached.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 01, 2007 19:55 ET (23:55 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: UPDATE: Court Sentences Hanwha Group Chairman To 18 Mos Jail
Story: (Adds details)     SEOUL (AP)--Hanwha Group (HWG.YY) Chairman Kim Seung-youn was sentenced to one year and six months in prison Monday over a sensational beating attack earlier this year against bar workers who had scuffled with his son.   The Seoul District Court handed down the ruling. Prosecutors last month sought a two-year prison term for Kim for ordering his bodyguards to attack the off-duty bar workers who had taken part in the scuffle with his 22-year-old son.   In his first trial session last month, Kim admitted to punching the bar workers during the attack in March but denied using a steel pipe or a stun gun as alleged by the victims.   The 55-year-old tycoon, one of South Korea's richest people, also said he was the one who "mainly beat" them and that his bodyguards took over when he "got tired."   Kim has been in jail since his May 11 arrest.   The dramatic details of the case, which the media have likened to something out of a gangster movie, have drawn intense public interest in South Korea, where the heads of family controlled conglomerates wield great economic, political and social clout.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 01, 2007 21:43 ET (01:43 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Fiat,China Partner Agree To Up JV Invest By CNY3B Each-Report
Story: SHANGHAI (Dow Jones)--Italian car maker Fiat SpA (FIA) and its Chinese partner Nanjing Automobile Corp. have agreed to increase their investments in a joint venture by about CNY3 billion each, the state-run Shanghai Securities News reported over the weekend.   The report, which didn't reveal its sources, said both parties reached the agreement with the moderation of the local authorities in Jiangsu province, adding that Nanjing Automobile will fund its investment with bank loans.   Fiat had planned to terminate its partnership with Nanjing Automobile after the Chinese company failed to make its promised investment in the joint-venture project, the newspaper reported in June.   The weekend report also said Nanjing Automobile had demanded Fiat not partner with another Chinese carmaker, Chery Automobile Co., but withdrew the condition later, adding that Fiat is expected to announce its partnership with Chery Automobile before August.   The state-run China Daily in February cited an unnamed industry source as saying Chery Automobile was in talks with Fiat on expanding their ties and among the options would be a joint venture in China to assemble Fiat cars. In October, Fiat signed an agreement with Chery to buy 100,000 engines for cars built in China and overseas.     Newspaper Web site: http://www.cnstock.com     -By China Bureau, Dow Jones Newswires; 8621 6120-1200; djnews.shanghai@dowjones.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 01, 2007 06:12 ET (10:12 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: WSJ(7/2) Wal-Mart Picks Head For Home-Decor Unit
Story: (From THE WALL STREET JOURNAL)     By Kris Hudson   Wal-Mart Stores Inc. hired former Kraft Foods Inc. executive Linda Hefner to oversee its ailing home-decor division.   Ms. Hefner, who left Kraft last year in an executive-suite shake-up, was named executive vice president and general manager of Wal-Mart's home division. She reports to Chief Merchandising Officer John Fleming and oversees the home division's strategy, brand management, product development and sourcing.   Wal-Mart doesn't disclose sales tallies for its home unit, which encompasses small appliances, furniture, bedding and decor, among other merchandise. However, the Bentonville, Ark., retailer has pinned much of the blame for its paltry sales gains at established stores in the past year on weak sales from its home division and, more so, its apparel division. The two units were cornerstones of Wal-Mart's failed effort in 2005 and 2006 to broaden its customer base to include more trend-conscious, affluent shoppers.   Ms. Hefner, previously an executive vice president at Kraft, left the Northfield, Ill., company in recent months after new CEO Irene Rosenfeld shuffled several top jobs. Prior to her work at Kraft, Ms. Hefner served in various executive roles at Sara Lee Corp., from 1989 to 2003. A Wal-Mart spokeswoman said Ms. Hefner was unavailable for comment.   Prior to a shake-up this year in which Mr. Fleming shifted from overseeing Wal-Mart's marketing to leading its merchandising, both the home and apparel divisions were the responsibility of Executive Vice President Claire Watts. She now oversees apparel only.   The home division has seen further changes: Lucy Cindric, previously a senior vice president of the division's soft goods, left Wal-Mart this year. Meanwhile, Beth Schommer arrived as a senior vice president over both soft goods and hard goods.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 01, 2007 19:53 ET (23:53 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: WSJ(7/2) Tech Led US IPO Market In June
Story: (From THE WALL STREET JOURNAL)     By Yvonne Ball   It was a tale of two IPO markets in June as technology stocks proved a boon for investors, but private-equity firm Blackstone Group's public offering fell flat and a handful of deals were pulled on the eve of their scheduled debut.   Blackstone's $4.75 billion public offering failed to match the hype as Wall Street counted down the days to the firm's much publicized debut on June 22.   Despite reports the IPO was seven times oversubscribed, Blackstone rallied only 13% on its first day of trading. It closed Friday 5.6% below its $31-a-share offering price as analysts debate whether the stock is overvalued and wary investors wonder whether the IPO signaled a peak in the private-equity boom.   Whether the deal, which delivered a massive payday to Blackstone's executives, entices rival private-equity firms to go public, remains to be seen. Rival Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Co., the buyout firm that became famous for its takeover of RJR Nabisco in the 1980s, is planning an IPO.   "I think the asset class remains to be an asset class that investors are going to be very intrigued by," said Mark Hantho, Deutsche Bank's vice chairman and head of equity and equity-linked capital markets for the Americas.   Blackstone was one of 18 companies that went public in June, according to Dealogic, after four deals on the calendar were postponed or withdrawn.   Among the casualties was telecommunications company ShoreTel Inc. which was hit by a lawsuit alleging infringement of four patents from Ottawa-based Mitel Networks Corp. on the eve of its scheduled debut last week.   The 18 public offerings, which exclude real-estate investment companies and special-purpose acquisition companies, matched the number of IPOs in June 2006 but fell short of the 27 companies that went public in May, the busiest month so far this year.   The volume of deals may have eased, but the money raised skyrocketed.   Blackstone's IPO, the fourth-largest in the U.S. ever, increased the value of all offerings in the past month to $7.4 billion, almost 40% more than the amount raised in May and almost three times that raised in June last year.   Indeed, the value of the 18 deals in June fell only 11% short of the total amount raised in November, when 32 deals raised $8.2 billion.   Overall, 104 IPOs have raised about $26.2 billion this year, compared with 89 deals that raised $20.9 billion in the first half of 2006.   "There's everything to be very positive about," Mr. Hantho said. "The access to capital from both companies that are already public and also for companies that want to go public has been very well received."   Technology was easily the best-performing sector in June, accounting for eight deals that gained an average of 25% on their first day of trading. It compares with an average first-day return of 15% for all IPOs.   Data-storage company Data Domain, which went public last week, soared 66%, making it the second-best IPO this year behind hedge-fund Fortress Investment Group, which rallied 68% on its first day of trading in February.   "We have a two-tiered market going. One is technology, and then there are all the others," said John Fitzgibbon, an IPO analyst and founder of IPOScoop.com.   "In terms of the IPOs that were postponed, it's a case-by-case situation. There's nothing to worry about from that standpoint."   While the IPO calendar is bare in early July, the week of July 16 is filling up quickly. Among those penciled in is MF Global Ltd.'s $4.18 billion offering.   "We're going to be in for one great summer, and technology will be leading the way," Mr. Fitzgibbon said.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 01, 2007 19:38 ET (23:38 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Financial News: Italian Investors Hold Key To LSE Future
Story: By Luke Jeffs and David Rothnie   Of FINANCIAL NEWS     The Italian banks that own 25% of the London Stock Exchange Group PLC (LSE.LN) will be free to sell their shares as soon as its GBP1.1 billion (EUR1.6 billion) takeover of Borsa Italiana completes.   This development comes as a mystery investor has taken 6% of the LSE and it emerged that the boss of Italian banking group UniCredit SpA (UC.MI), which will become a 5% holder in the U.K. exchange, would back a merger between the LSE and Deutsche Boerse.   The decision by LSE not to lock in the 12 Italian banks, whose majority shareholding in Borsa Italiana will convert to LSE if the merger goes through, was greeted with surprise by industry insiders and could put pressure on the LSE's share price. A banker close to the deal said it was not necessary to lock in the banks. He said: "We expect them to be long-term holders."   LSE chief executive Clara Furse is adamant the merger will go through, despite a fall in the exchange's share price and uncertainty over the position of its largest shareholder, Nasdaq, the U.S. exchange that was forced to abandon a hostile bid for the LSE in February.   It is understood Furse has sufficient backing to allow the deal to go through from shareholders controlling 30% of the company.   ABN Amro (ABN) last week emerged as the third largest shareholder in the LSE, having bought 6.1% of the stock on behalf of clients. The bank, the lead adviser on Euronext's (29064.AE) merger with the New York Stock Exchange, has bought 12.3 million shares in recent weeks, and over 6 million in two days at the end of last month, paying about GBP13.50 a share.   ABN Amro's buying spree came as the LSE said it was in merger talks with Borsa Italiana. The bank broke the 3% limit, above which investors are obliged to declare their holdings, on June 22, the day before the exchanges announced their agreement to merge.   The exchange said ABN Amro is not the owner and the bank has acquired the shares on behalf of a third party, possibly a hedge fund. ABN Amro confirmed it is holding the shares but gave no further information.   Italian newspapers suggested that Alessandro Profumo, chief executive of UniCredit, would back a merger between the LSE and Deutsche Boerse. He is a member of the supervisory board of the German exchange.     Web site: http://www.efinancialnews.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 01, 2007 20:01 ET (00:01 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: WSJ(7/2) Some IPhones Are Stuck On Hold
Story: (From THE WALL STREET JOURNAL)     By Amol Sharma and Nick Wingfield   AT&T Inc. said it was working to resolve problems preventing some buyers of Apple Inc.'s iPhone from activating the device, in a hiccup for one of the most eagerly awaited electronics products in years.   About 2% of those who purchased an iPhone experienced problems activating phone service, according to a person familiar with the situation.   Phone activation also activates the iPhone's other features, such as playing music or movies and Web surfing.   The problems likely would have to linger or broaden to blunt the overall impact of the iPhone for the two companies. Neither disclosed sales, although industry observers -- citing crowded stores, media buzz and strong consumer interest -- expect the new product to be a strong seller.   Still, the wrinkle illustrates the complexities Apple faces in offering a consumer product that plugs into a cellular network, as well as working with a partner. Apple developed the iPhone device and its software, and AT&T has an exclusive, multiyear contract with Apple to provide cellular service for the device.   In blog postings and emails to The Wall Street Journal, some consumers who lined up at Apple and AT&T stores complained of problems and delays as they tried to get the phone running through Apple's iTunes computer software.   Some AT&T customers said their existing cellphones had been deactivated while they were still waiting for their iPhone to be activated, leaving them without any working phone.   AT&T spokesman Michael Coe said the vast majority of iPhone buyers were able to activate the device "within minutes." He added, "We're working to get those problems resolved. It's getting better and better." Apple spokeswoman Natalie Kerris said only, "the response to iPhone has been incredible. We're thrilled there's so much excitement."   Jared Gurfein, president of spirits company Viridian Spirits LLC, bought his iPhone at an Apple store Friday evening on New York's Long Island, but hasn't been able to use the device since then.   "I'm at the point of frustration where, as much as I'd like to get the device to work, I'd just like to get my BlackBerry working again."     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 01, 2007 19:45 ET (23:45 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: UK Oil Rig Builder SeaDragon Mulls $1B IPO -Newspaper
Story: DOW JONES NEWSWIRES   SeaDragon, the London-based exploration rig builder, has appointed ABN Amro to consider its options as it mulls a possible initial public offering that could value the company at up to $1 billion, according to The Independent. Headline: WSJ(7/2) Stock Market Quarterly Review: Private Equity Fuels Record Merger Run
Story: (From THE WALL STREET JOURNAL)     By Dana Cimilluca   Storm clouds may be gathering on the horizon, but the sun is shining brightly on the mergers-and-acquisitions market.   Companies around the world struck $1.65 trillion of merger deals in the second quarter, eclipsing the first quarter of 2000 as the biggest three-month total, according to data tracker Thomson Financial.   That is a 90% increase from the same period in 2006, which racked up a full-year deal-making total of $3.6 trillion, the best on record. With deal volume in the first quarter of this year rising 28% to just under $1 trillion, that 2006 record would be easily shattered if the pace of the first half of 2007 is sustained.   The second quarter could end up being a high-water mark, as the flood of cheap credit that has lubricated the buyout boom shows signs of ebbing.   Bond and loan investors in recent days have forced a raft of companies that are going private to pay higher interest rates and agree to more lender-friendly contract terms. If the recent bout of volatility proves to be the beginning of a more drastic reduction in the availability of credit, bankers say, the days of the record merger run could be numbered.   "We're starting to get to the point where we may not be able to sustain this breathtaking pace," says Paul J. Taubman, the head of the global M&A group at Morgan Stanley, the No. 2 adviser on deals in terms of value after Goldman Sachs Group Inc. this year. "The M&A marketplace is going to have a meaningful correction if all of a sudden easy credit disappears."   After going into a deep freeze following corporate-governance scandals and the bursting of the technology-stock bubble early this decade, merger activity roared back in late 2003, with deals such as the $41 billion purchase of AT&T Wireless by Cingular Wireless, which is now part of AT&T Inc.   Besides the explosion of private-equity buyouts, the boom has been fueled by ample cash on corporate balance sheets and the rising confidence among executives that comes with increasing profits and share prices.   Fittingly for a quarter in which the value of deals struck in Europe exceeded those in the U.S., the largest acquisitions announced in the past three months were in Europe.   The biggest was the announced takeover of Dutch bank ABN Amro Holding NV by British bank Barclays PLC. That offer -- valued at about $91 billion when it was announced -- was later topped by a $97 billion bid by a group including Royal Bank of Scotland Group PLC. It remains to be seen which of the two offers, both announced in April, will prevail.   Next on the list was the $31 billion acquisition of Spanish electricity company Endesa SA by Italian utility Enel SpA and Spanish conglomerate Acciona. The April 2 agreement ended an 18-month takeover battle that pitted Enel and Acciona against E.On AG of Germany and Gas Natural SDG SA of Spain.   The third-biggest deal was UniCredito Italiano SpA's May 20 merger pact with rival Italian bank Capitalia SpA for nearly $30 billion.   Underscoring the contribution of private-equity firms to the M&A boom in the U.S. were three leveraged buyouts valued at more than $25 billion each. They are the purchases of wireless-phone company Alltel Corp., student lender SLM Corp. and credit-card processor First Data Corp.   According to Thomson, buyout firms accounted for 40% of U.S. M&A activity in the quarter, the highest level ever. That is why the overall M&A market is sensitive to any interruption in easy credit.   Saturday, after Thomson closed its books for the quarter, one of the largest LBOs was announced. A group led by the Ontario Teachers' Pension Plan that includes two big U.S. private-equity firms agreed to buy Canadian telecommunications operator BCE Inc. for about $32.6 billion, excluding debt.   Amid fears that the subprime-mortgage meltdown will spill over and the near collapse of two Bear Stearns Cos. hedge funds, a number of high-yield, or junk, debt issuers have had to scrap features of their offerings that had become a hallmark of the good times for borrowers.   Companies including Ahold NV's U.S. Foodservice unit that have agreed to be acquired abandoned slices of debt offerings that were to be so-called pay-in-kind toggle notes. The bonds can pay cash interest or not, based on the issuer's preference.   Some bankers predict that such bonds are a thing of the past.   "We've seen the froth come off private equity," says H. Rodgin Cohen, chairman of New York law firm Sullivan & Cromwell LLP, which is the No. 1 law-firm adviser on deals in the first half by total dollar value, according to Thomson. "But at the same time there are still a lot of good private-equity deals. There's no reason that should slow down. I suspect we'll see a pretty good third quarter."   A number of bankers agree that psychology among lenders will be crucial in determining how much longer the good times last.   A "sentiment shift" among credit investors could endanger the health of the credit markets, Goldman Sachs Chief Executive Lloyd Blankfein said at a conference last week in New York sponsored by The Wall Street Journal.   Some bankers say it is too early to sound alarms about the end of the buyout boom. Jimmy Elliott, co-head of global M&A at J.P. Morgan Chase & Co., says the credit-market tremors aren't enough to sap private equity's interest in buyouts.   "There would need to be a significant shift in the cost of debt to dampen the spirits of financial sponsors," Mr. Elliott says, using bankers' parlance for private-equity firms.   He said share-price declines that accompanied losses in the debt market will lessen the cost of acquisitions for private-equity firms and might offset higher borrowing costs.   "I don't think we're on the way down yet," he says. "I believe we're on a plateau."   ---   Dennis K. Berman contributed to this article.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 01, 2007 21:00 ET (01:00 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Australia's Westfield Establishes UK Shopping Center Fund
Story: SYDNEY (Dow Jones)--Australian-based global shopping center owner Westfield Group (WDC.AU) said Monday it has established a A$1.25 billion wholesale fund that will hold a 25% stake in four U.K. shopping centers.   The fund will own 25% stakes in Westfield's centers at Merry Hill, Belfast and Tunbridge Wells, and will buy a 25% stake in its Derby center by October 2009, after its current redevelopment is completed.   Westfield will manage the fund and continue to manage the centers, while two unnamed cornerstone investors have subscribed for 67% of the fund, said Westfield in a statement. The remaining 33% will be marketed to a wider group of wholesale investors.   The transaction is not expected to materially affect earnings or distributions this year, and Westfield will retain a 25% interest in the four properties.     -By Bill Lindsay, Dow Jones Newswires; 61-2-8235-2956; bill.lindsay@dowjones.com   -Edited by Paul Dekkers     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 01, 2007 20:34 ET (00:34 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: : deCODE Discovers a Variation in the Sequence of the Genome Conferring Risk of Atrial Fibrillation
Story: Launches deCODE AF(TM), A Test for the Risk Variant Aimed at the Prevention of Stroke       REYKJAVIK, Iceland, July 1 /PRNewswire-FirstCall/ -- A paper published today in the journal Nature describes the discovery by scientists at deCODE genetics (Nasdaq: DCGN), in collaboration with academic colleagues in Iceland, the United States, Sweden and China, of two common single-letter variations in the genome (SNPs) conferring risk of atrial fibrillation (AF). AF is the most common cardiac arrhythmia and is also the leading cause of cardiogenic stroke. The variants, located on chromosome 4q25, confer an approximately 70% and 40% increase above average risk of AF, respectively, per copy carried. Approximately one third of people of European ancestry carry at least one copy of one of the risk variants, and deCODE's results show that those who carry two copies of the more powerful variant are at a more than 250% greater likelihood of AF than those who carry neither variant. The gene nearest to these SNPs, PITX2, is known to play an important role in the development of the heart.     deCODE also today launched deCODE AF(TM), a reference laboratory test for the variants. Because AF is the biggest risk factor for cardiogenic stroke, the company believes that testing for these variants will provide doctors with a targeted and cost-effective means of identifying those who should be intensively monitored for AF. Current best clinical practice recommends that stroke patients with AF can significantly reduce their risk of a second stroke by taking the anticoagulant drug warfarin.     "This is an important discovery with an immediate clinical application. Transient AF is difficult to detect in many patients, and it is impractical and too costly to conduct extended cardiac monitoring on all patients with stroke and transient ischemic attack. With the discovery of these variants, and the availability of a test to detect them, doctors may now be able focus monitoring on those most likely to have transient AF and then match therapy to the etiology of an individual's disease. This study is also impressive in that it took us only seven months from the beginning of the search for AF variants to today's publication and the launch of the test. This speaks very clearly to the power of our gene discovery capabilities and our product development group," said Kari Stefansson, CEO of deCODE and a board-certified neurologist.     deCODE discovered the variants, the "T" alleles of SNPs rs2200733 and rs10033464, through analysis of more than more than 300,000 SNPs in a total of more than 5,000 Icelanders with atrial fibrillation and/or atrial flutter as well as healthy control subjects. These findings were subsequently replicated in case-control cohorts from Iceland, the Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston, and the Karolinska Institute in Stockholm, including a total of 18,000 subjects. The stronger variant was also confirmed in a Han Chinese population from Hong Kong. In this group the variant conferred a slightly smaller increase in risk than in the other cohorts, but 75% of those studied carried at least one copy. Thus while the population-attributable risk (PAR) - roughly the proportion of cases that not exist were these variants not present - of the two variants in people European ancestry is approximately 20%, the first variant alone has a PAR of nearly 35% in Han Chinese. The article is published today in the online edition of Nature at www.nature.com and will appear in an upcoming print edition of the journal.        How to order deCODE AF(TM)     deCODE AF(TM) is performed in deCODE's Clinical Laboratory Improvement Amendments (CLIA) certified laboratory, and must be authorized by a qualified physician. If you are a doctor interested in learning more about deCODE T2(TM) for your patients, or an individual who would like more information to discuss with your doctor, we invite you to visit our website, at www.decodediagnostics.com.        About deCODE     deCODE is a biopharmaceutical company applying its discoveries in human genetics to the development of drugs and diagnostics for common diseases. deCODE is a global leader in gene discovery - our population approach and resources have enabled us to isolate key genes contributing to major public health challenges from cardiovascular disease to cancer, genes that are providing us with drug targets rooted in the basic biology of disease. deCODE is also leveraging its expertise in human genetics and integrated drug discovery and development capabilities to offer innovative products and services in DNA-based diagnostics, bioinformatics, genotyping, structural biology, drug discovery and clinical development. deCODE is delivering on the promise of the new genetics(SM). Visit us on the web at www.decode.com.     Any statements contained in this presentation that relate to future plans, events or performance are forward-looking statements within the meaning of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995.  These forward-looking statements are subject to a number of risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially from those described in the forward- looking statements.  These risks and uncertainties include, among others, those relating to technology and product development, integration of acquired businesses, market acceptance, government regulation and regulatory approval processes, intellectual property rights and litigation, dependence on collaborative relationships, ability to obtain financing, competitive products, industry trends and other risks identified in deCODE's filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission.  deCODE undertakes no obligation to update or alter these forward-looking statements as a result of new information, future events or otherwise.           Contact:       deCODE genetics         Edward Farmer              Berglind Olafsdottir    Joy Bessenger       +1 212 343 2819            +354 664 2393           +1 212 481 3891       edward.farmer@decode.is    bro@decode.is           ir@decode.is      SOURCE  deCODE genetics       /CONTACT: Edward Farmer, +1-212-343-2819, edward.farmer@decode.is, or Berglind Olafsdottir, +354-664-2393, bro@decode.is, or Joy Bessenger, +1-212-481-3891, ir@decode.is, all of deCODE genetics      /Web site: http://www.decode.com      /Web site: http://www.decodediagnostics.com      /Web site: http://www.nature.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 01, 2007 13:08 ET (17:08 GMT)

Headline: Australia's Wesfarmers: Permira Out Of Coles Bid; PEP Talks
Story: MELBOURNE (Dow Jones)--Australia's Wesfarmers Ltd. (WES.AU) confirmed Monday that London-based buyout company Permira (PR.YY) has pulled out of the bidding for retailer Coles Group Ltd. (CGJ.AU).   Permira, which planned to take a stake in Coles' core food and liquor business alongside Wesfarmers, withdrew because of the state of the U.S. debt market, a spokesman for Wesfarmers said.   Wesfarmers remains in talks to acquire Coles, with both companies' shares placed in trading halt.   Wesfarmers may raise the planned equity proportion of its offer to 60% from 40%, another person familiar with situation told Dow Jones Newswires.   Permira was part of a leveraged syndicate which included local buyout company Pacific Equity Partners and Australia's Macquarie Bank Ltd.   The spokesman said Wesfarmers remained in talks with PEP, but its role hasn't yet been defined.   Macquarie also remains an adviser to the consortium.       -By Susan Murdoch, Dow Jones Newswires; 61-3-9671-4393; susan.murdoch@dowjones.com     -Edited by Graham Morgan     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 01, 2007 21:35 ET (01:35 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: WSJ(7/2) UPDATE: BCE Faces $32.6B Buyout
Story: (From THE WALL STREET JOURNAL)     By Sarah Childress and Dennis K. Berman   The $32.6 billion buyout of Canadian telecommunications operator BCE Inc. represents the largest private-equity deal in history and a sign that despite some market jitters, the buyout route remains an active option for boards and managers.   BCE said it agreed to be acquired by the investment arm of Ontario Teachers' Pension Plan, Providence Equity Partners Inc. and Madison Dearborn Partners for $32.6 billion. The deal also includes an additional $15.9 billion in debt, preferred equity and minority interests, for a total value of $48.5 billion, making it also the largest private-equity buyout package in history. The buyers are writing equity checks valued at $8 billion, according to a person familiar with the transaction.   In recent years, private-equity firms have pursued national telecom companies like BCE, which are often threatened by more-nimble rivals. Providence, for example, has been part of groups that acquired two national telecoms companies in recent years: Ireland's Eircom in 2001 and the Danish company TDC in 2006.   This deal is another in a crescendo of buyouts in which private-equity firms take on increasingly greater targets, looking for ways to spend ever-larger troughs of cash, collecting fat management and transaction fees along the way.   "The plan in private equity is to go after bigger and bigger deals, and this is yet another level," says Shahid Khan, a partner at Interactive Broadband Consulting Group.   Under the deal, the buyout group will purchase BCE's shares for 42.75 Canadian dollars, or US$40.12, a 40% premium over the average first-quarter share price before it rose in late March amid rumors of a buyout. Friday, BCE's shares were priced at $37.79 in 4 p.m. composite trading on the New York Stock Exchange.   The deal puts leverage of about six times BCE's cash flow on the company, a relatively low figure by today's buyout standards, but still an aggressive number for a business with stagnant revenue and profits. A group of banks including Citigroup Inc., Deutsche Bank AG, Royal Bank of Scotland Group PLC and TD Securities are arranging the debt financing. A person familiar with the matter said that only about $500 million of the debt would come via bridge loans by the banks, a relatively low number by current deal standards. Such loans, which are short-term until other financing can be arranged, have been a source of worry amid troubles in the debt markets.   The deal still must be approved by BCE's shareholders and cleared by Canada's Competition Bureau. Ontario Teachers' Pension Plan is already BCE's largest shareholder.   BCE dominates the telecom market in Eastern Canada, selling fixed-line, wireless, high-speed Internet and video services. The company's stock had stagnated in recent years as the company struggled to stay competitive. BCE had trouble signing up subscribers to its Bell Wireless cellphone unit and its land-line division lost access lines to cheaper cable providers. Meanwhile, smaller rivals Telus Corp. and Rogers Communications Inc. both saw overall growth.   Despite interest from several private-equity groups, BCE was widely expected to be taken over by Telus, its leading rival. But last week, Telus decided not to submit a bid, citing "inadequacies" in the bidding process. It still could enter a friendly or hostile bid. "For traditional companies like Telus, it's very difficult for them to go out and compete with private-equity shops," says Mr. Khan, of Interactive Broadband. Telus would have to expend much more capital and risk stock fluctuations, he says, and likely wouldn't return to the table unless it has an unbeatable deal. A Telus spokesman declined to comment yesterday.   Aside from Teachers, Cerberus Capital Management and the Hospitals of Ontario Pension Plan submitted a bid, as well as the Canadian Pension Plan Investment Board and buyout firm Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Co., despite a last-minute pullout of partners Caisse de Depot et Placement du Quebec in Montreal and Onex Corp. All are major Canadian funds partnered with U.S. private-equity firms because, according to federal law, foreign companies can own no more than 46.67% of telecom providers.   Yesterday, the Cerberus group was still considering its options, a person familiar with the matter said. This person said the group was frustrated with what it felt was an expedited bidding process. The group had presented a plan that would have offered $44 a share -- $38 in cash with an additional guarantee of $6 if BCE's price fell below $44. A BCE spokesman declined to comment.   BCE reported first-quarter net income of C$529 million on revenue of C$4.39 billion.   BCE was advised by Goldman Sachs, BMO Capital Markets, CIBC Capital Markets, and RBC Capital Markets. Greenhill & Co. advised a separate oversight board committee. Davies, Ward Phillips & Vineberg; Stikeman Elliott; and Sullivan & Cromwell provided legal advice. Citigroup was advised by Citigroup, Deutsche Bank, Royal Bank of Scotland and TD Securities, with legal advice from Weil, Gotshal & Manges and Goodmans.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 01, 2007 22:30 ET (02:30 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Hitachi To Offer Large LCD TVs In China, Europe - Report
Story: TOKYO (Dow Jones)--Hitachi Ltd. (6501.TO) plans to this fall begin offering large-screen TVs with liquid crystal displays in China and Europe, two regions where its plasma display TVs have struggled, reports the Yomiuri Shimbun.   Hitachi had been focusing mainly on plasma display large-screen TVs, but sales have suffered in some regions due to the lower-priced liquid crystal display televisions offered by its competitors.   For these regions Hitachi now plans to offer both plasma and LCD televisions, the report said.     -By Tokyo Bureau, Dow Jones Newswires; 813-5255-2929     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 01, 2007 19:11 ET (23:11 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Gazprom Official Defends Policy Abroad - TV
Story: MOSCOW (AP)--A top Gazprom official defended the natural-gas giant's aggressive foreign activity in an interview broadcast Sunday, dismissing European concerns about reliance on Russian gas and saying the company has reserves to match its wide-ranging plans.   Deputy Gazprom CEO Alexander Medvedev, the head of the state-controlled monopoly's export arm, said that European nations have little alternative to gas from Russia and other major sources over the next quarter-century or more. He suggested that talk of the need for diversification is misguided.   "When in the long-term perspective only three countries in the world possess resources of gas that can satisfy demand over the next 25-30 years and on...I cannot quite imagine what kind of diversification we are talking about," he said.   In the interview with state-run Vesti-24 television, Medvedev said Russia is providing "real diversification - diversification of transport routes, creation of underground storage capacity, where all risks - technological, transit-related, seasonal, weather-related - are, if not removed, then significantly lessened by this approach."   Russia currently supplies a quarter of Europe's oil and more than two-fifths of its gas. OAO Gazprom is seeking transit and distribution deals, including through the acquisition of shares in European energy companies, as part of a campaign to boost its presence in the region.   Moscow's reputation as an energy supplier was tarnished after sudden oil and gas shutdowns at the start of 2006 and 2007 amid politically charged price fights with ex-Soviet neighbors and led to shortfalls in supplies to the European Union.   Russia's increasing control of oil and natural gas supplies is causing concern in western European capitals, and both European and U.S. officials have accused Moscow of using its energy might as a political weapon.   Medvedev said Gazprom's strategy abroad was motivated by "purely economic factors."   He also dismissed questions about whether the company has reserves to back its expansive moves.   "We have enough gas for all contracts that are foreseen, both existing contracts and contracts that have not yet been signed, including gas for new markets - gas for supplies to China, Korea, gas for liquefaction and in general for supplies to the Asia-Pacific region and to the U.S. and Canadian markets," he said.   "So our long-term gas balance is fully provided for by our reserves and our transport capabilities."     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 01, 2007 10:50 ET (14:50 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Hometrack: UK June House Prices +0.3% On Mo, +6.4% On Year
Story: LONDON (Dow Jones)--U.K. house price growth slowed for the second straight month in June as the supply of available property increased and higher interest rates weighed on the market, property valuation company Hometrack said Monday.   The average U.K. house price rose 0.3% on the month in June, compared with growth of 0.6% in May, Hometrack said. The annual rise in prices eased to 6.4% from 6.7% in May.   "The growth in supply comes at a time when demand is faltering on the back of recent increases in interest rates and widespread fears of further rate rises to come," said Richard Donnell, Hometrack's director of research.   "With much of the new supply coming to the market from discretionary sellers looking to achieve close to the full asking price, it seems likely that the average time to sell property will increase in the months ahead with a slowdown in sales volumes and a switch to a buyers market," he said.   The Bank of England's Monetary Policy Committee has delivered four 25-basis-point hikes since last August to bring its benchmark interest rate to 5.5% in a bid to slow inflation.   Earlier this month the bank's MPC voted 5-4 in favor of leaving rates steady, prompting many economists to bring forward their forecasts for the next rate hike to July and increasing market expectations for rates to rise to 6% by the end of the year.   The rate hikes have translated to higher mortgage payments for many homeowners and made buyers think twice before borrowing. In London, where house prices have risen strongly for 18 months, prices fell 3.5% in June from the corresponding month in 2006. On the month, prices in London rose 0.7% in June after increasing 1.3% in May.   "The ratcheting up of interest rates since summer last year has finally caught up with the London market, which has been the engine for house price growth over the last 12 months," Donnell said. "Housing market sentiment appears to be turning with buyers likely to become increasingly price sensitive over the second half of the year."   Nevertheless, Hometrack still expects U.K. house prices to rise 4% this year.   Elsewhere in the U.K., house prices rose 0.4% on the month in east Anglia and 0.3% in south east England. Prices were 0.2% higher in south west England, the west midlands and Yorkshire and Humberside. House prices rose 0.1% in northern England, the north west and in Wales and were unchanged in the east midlands.   The survey also showed the average time taken to sell a property had fallen for the third straight month to 6 weeks with an average number of viewings of 10.8. The sales price achieved as a percentage of the sellers asking price, meanwhile was 95.6%.                                       June           May                             On Mo   On Yr  On Mo   On Yr     Nationwide    +1.1%  +11.1%  +0.5%  +10.3%     Halifax                   N/A     N/A   +0.3%  +10.6%     Rightmove     +0.8%  +13.2%  +0.4%  +13.1%     Hometrack     +0.3%   +6.4%  +0.6%   +6.7%     Web site: www.hometrack.co.uk     -By Ilona Billington, Dow Jones Newswires; +44 7 842 9452; ilona.billington@dowjones.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 01, 2007 19:01 ET (23:01 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: WSJ(7/2) Finding The Best Measure Of `Corporate Citizenship'
Story: (From THE WALL STREET JOURNAL)     By Phred Dvorak   Does good corporate behavior pay off in the stock market? Companies that track corporate governance and share performance say "yes" -- and investors agree.   But it's not always easy for investors to act on that notion. There's little consensus over what "good governance" is and how it should be measured. In the resulting muddle, it's sometimes hard to know who's a "good" corporate citizen.   Take Internet superstar Google Inc. The company made the 2007 "World's Most Ethical Companies" list of governance-tracker Ethisphere, because of its strong code of conduct and positive customer views of its behavior. But Audit Integrity Inc., which scrutinizes accounting behavior and litigation risk, ranks Google poorly. One recent red flag: Viacom Inc.'s copyright lawsuit against Google and its newly acquired YouTube video-sharing site. A Google spokesman says the strong Ethisphere rating reflects "our unwavering commitment to serving our users" but says he is unfamiliar with Audit Integrity.   The attention to governance and share performance comes in the wake of corporate shipwrecks such as Enron Corp., where shady accounting practices and lax oversight cost investors billions of dollars. GovernanceMetrics International Inc. began rating listed companies in 2002, in an attempt to assess their vulnerability to that sort of risk, says Chief Executive Howard Sherman. The company sells its ratings and research, as well as governance-consulting services.   GovernanceMetrics rates nearly 4,000 public companies globally, grading them on more than 400 variables, from financial restatements to training for directors. As of February, 40 companies had scored GovernanceMetrics' top grade of 10, including Chevron Corp. and Sun Microsystems Inc.   GovernanceMetrics says its highly ranked companies outperform others. "Good governance translates into trust, and trust determines what you're willing to pay" for a company's shares, says Mr. Sherman.   Analysts at Swiss private bank Lombard Odier Darier Hentsch & Cie. use GovernanceMetrics' ratings to assess the risks of investments and potential investments. "Good corporate-governance practices will improve the value of a firm in the next years," says LODH analyst Jean-Cristophe Rochat.   Experts debate the importance of such ratings. Skeptics say studies of governance practices and share performance are skewed by other factors, such as an industry's results. Many studies are sponsored by companies that sell governance ratings or consulting services -- giving them a vested interest in showing their numbers are significant.   Moreover, once information about a company's governance practices is known, it is quickly priced into the stock. That means shares of companies with good governance ratings may not continue to post strong returns, says Shane Johnson, a finance professor at Texas A&M University and co-author of a recent paper on the subject.   Audit Integrity, another governance-tracking firm launched after the Enron scandal, says its ratings and research are used by insurers, auditors and asset managers. It also claims corporate good guys perform better than bad guys -- but uses very different measures than GovernanceMetrics to identify them.   It grades 8,000 companies on issues such as board independence and executive compensation, and  also analyzes the companies' accounting, penalizing murky bookkeeping methods. Audit Integrity then ranks companies' likelihood of being sued, restating results and underperforming the market.   The result: Audit Integrity and Governance Metrics offer very different lists of good guys. The only top GovernanceMetrics scorer that appears in Audit Integrity's top 100 is Louisiana-based energy company Entergy Corp.   Sabrient Systems LLC, which creates stock-picking models for professional investors, found Audit Integrity's ratings help boost performance by weeding out companies with risky governance practices, says director David Brown. Mr. Brown says he's now looking at other corporate-governance measures, although he finds the varied approaches confusing. "I wish they all did it the same way," he says.   Audit Integrity Chairman and founder James Kaplan says the company tried -- and failed -- to find a connection between share performance and corporate governance alone. After including the accounting analysis, however, the firm's top-rated large companies posted better returns than the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index.   Then there is Ethisphere, which ranked Google highly and is partly funded by ethics and compliance consultant Corpedia Inc. Ethisphere rates companies on issues such as transparency and the strength of compliance systems, then asks a company's suppliers and customers to rate its behavior. Ethisphere compares companies only with peers in the same industry, says Alex Brigham, Corpedia's CEO. Ethisphere says the 65 publicly traded companies on its top-ranked list outperformed the S&P 500 over the past five years.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 01, 2007 19:49 ET (23:49 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Liberty Intl Buys 50% Stake in Earls Court - Newspaper
Story: LONDON (Dow Jones)--U.K. real estate investment trust Liberty International PLC (LII.LN) has bought a 50% stake in London's Earls Court and Olympic exhibition and conference centers from property tycoons Anthony Lyons and Simon Conway, the Sunday Telegraph and Mail on Sunday report, without citing sources.   Both newspapers say the deal is due to be announced to the London Stock Exchange Monday, valuing the properties at about GBP470 million.   Liberty International was not immediately available to comment.   Newspaper Web site: http://www.telegraph.co.uk   Newspaper Web site: http://www.mailonsunday.co.uk   -London Bureau, Dow Jones Newswires; +44 (0)20 7842 9320     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 01, 2007 07:16 ET (11:16 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: `Ratatouille' Rules Weekend Box Office With $47.2M Debut
Story: LOS ANGELES (AP)--Disney has put a rodent on top of the box office, though not the studio's venerable mascot, Mickey Mouse.   "Ratatouille," an animated comedy about a gourmet rat that gets a chance to cook in a French restaurant, debuted as the No. 1 weekend movie with $47.2 million, according to studio estimates Sunday.   20th Century Fox's action thriller "Live Free or Die Hard," Bruce Willis's return as unstoppable cop John McClane, opened in second-place with $33.15 million. Since opening Wednesday, the movie has grossed $48.2 million.   In narrower release, Michael Moore's health care documentary "Sicko," released by the Weinstein Co. and Lionsgate, took in $4.5 million in its nationwide debut to finish at No. 9. The movie opened in one New York City theater a week earlier.   Focus Features' family drama "Evening," with an all-star cast that includes Meryl Streep, Vanessa Redgrave, Glenn Close and Claire Danes, opened at No. 10 with $3.5 million.   The previous weekend's No. 1 movie, Universal's "Evan Almighty," fell to No. 3 with $15.1 million, raising its 10-day total to $60.6 million. The movie's sharp 52% fall from opening weekend dims the studio's prospects for recouping the enormous $175 million production budget for the film.   While "Ratatouille" easily dominated the weekend, it had the smallest debut among releases by Disney's Pixar Animation unit since 1998's "A Bug's Life," which opened with $33.3 million. The other five Pixar films since then, among them "Toy Story 2," "Finding Nemo" and last year's "Cars," had opening weekends between $57.4 million and $70.5 million.   Chuck Viane, Disney's head of distribution, said "Ratatouille" was up against more competition than past Pixar flicks. With sparkling reviews for "Ratatouille," Disney is counting on the staying power at theaters that other Pixar films have had.   "Our whole idea was to set ourselves up for what we call the 10-day opening," Viane said of the upcoming Fourth of July week. "We look at this as one extended playtime. We're in this for the long haul. We're glad we're No. 1, but we're not trying to make this just a weekend wonder."   Willis returned to the "Die Hard" franchise after a 12-year absence, and as Sylvester Stallone did last year with "Rocky Balboa," he proved that an aging action hero still could pack theaters.   "John McClane is everyman. He's a hero, but he's thrust into situations, and I think people love that," said Bert Livingston, general sales manager for Fox. "He's clever, he's funny and he gets the job done."   "Sicko," Moore's dissection of the ills of U.S. health care, played in 441 theaters, about half the number for his last movie, 2004's $100 million hit "Fahrenheit 9/11." With a $23.9 million opening, "Fahrenheit 9/11" did five times as much business, though.   Still, "Sicko" had the second-best documentary debut ever behind "Fahrenheit 9/11." By comparison, "Ratatouille" opened in nearly 4,000 theaters, about nine times as many as "Sicko."   Harvey Weinstein, co-chairman of the Weinstein Co., said he wanted to roll "Sicko" out slowly to give it a longer shelf life and keep Moore's stand for universal health care on the front burner.   "The idea is to hold during the summer and just continue to build this thing," Weinstein said. "I just think the debate in this country is going to catch up with the movie, so we've got to keep it slow."   Weinstein and Moore said they hoped "Sicko" would do in the range of the $21.6 million total for the filmmaker's 2002 Academy Award winner "Bowling for Columbine."   If Sunday estimates hold, Hollywood's overall revenues will be up slightly, snapping a four-week downturn that has surprised analysts who had expected the industry to do record business this summer. The top-12 movies took in $146.7 million, up 2% from the same weekend last year.   "For now, I'm glad we broke the down streak," said Paul Dergarabedian, president of box-office tracker Media By Numbers. "Four down weekends turns into five, which turns into eight, and then we have a slump on our hands. We didn't want to go in that direction."   Estimated ticket sales for Friday through Sunday at U.S. and Canadian theaters, according to Media By Numbers LLC. Final figures will be released Monday.   1. "Ratatouille," $47.2 million.   2. "Live Free or Die Hard," $33.15 million.   3. "Evan Almighty," $15.1 million.   4. "1408," $10.6 million.   5. "Fantastic Four: Rise of the Silver Surfer," $9 million.   6. "Knocked Up," $7.4 million.   7. "Ocean's Thirteen," $6.05 million.   8. "Pirates of the Caribbean: At World's End," $5 million.   9. "Sicko," $4.5 million.   10. "Evening," $3.5 million.   ---   Universal Pictures and Focus Features are owned by NBC Universal, a joint venture of General Electric Co. and Vivendi Universal; Sony Pictures, Sony Screen Gems and Sony Pictures Classics are units of Sony Corp.; DreamWorks, Paramount and Paramount Vantage are divisions of Viacom Inc.; Disney's parent is The Walt Disney Co.; Miramax is a division of The Walt Disney Co.; 20th Century Fox, Fox Searchlight Pictures and Fox Atomic are owned by News Corp.; Warner Bros., New Line, Warner Independent and Picturehouse are units of Time Warner Inc.; MGM is owned by a consortium of Providence Equity Partners, Texas Pacific Group, Sony Corp., Comcast Corp., DLJ Merchant Banking Partners and Quadrangle Group; Lionsgate is owned by Lionsgate Entertainment Corp.; IFC Films is owned by Rainbow Media Holdings, a subsidiary of Cablevision Systems Corp.   AP-NY-07-01-07 1348EDT     (MORE TO FOLLOW) Dow Jones Newswires  July 01, 2007 19:10 ET (23:10 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Spain's Marsans Doesn't Rule Out Bid On Iberia -Newspaper
Story: DOW JONES NEWSWIRES   Spain's travel company, Grupo Marsans SA, is not ruling out a bid on Iberia Lineas Aereas de Espana SA (IBLA.MC) in the future, Gonzalo Pascual, chairman of Marsans and of airline Spanair, told El Mundo in an interview published in its Monday Internet edition.   "Marsans has the capacity of leading an offer to buy Iberia, for which we would count on external resources," Pascual told the newspaper, adding that there are institutions willing to finance EUR4 billion for an Iberia bid.   Marsans is looking to buy Spanair, the Spanish airline controlled by Scandinavian carrier SAS, and Pascual said that the outcome of the operation on Spanair will determine his company's posture on Iberia, according to El Mundo.   Newspaper Web site: http://www.elmundo.es   -Dow Jones Newswires; enza.tedesco@dowjones.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 01, 2007 22:33 ET (02:33 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Australia's Santos Completes A$300M Buyback
Story: MELBOURNE (Dow Jones)--Oil and gas producer Santos Ltd. (STO.AU) Monday said it has completed its A$320 million off-market share buyback with the price set at A$12.16.   Chief financial officer Peter Wasow said strong demand had allowed the company to buy back 4.1% of its issued capital at the maximum discount of 14%.   "The successful completion of the buyback will deliver additional benefits to shareholders through improvements in our capital structure while allowing us to continue to invest in our growth businesses," he said.   The strong interest meant there would be a 60.87% scale back applied, with shareholders who tendered their shares at 14% given a priority allocation of 500 shares.   For those who have tendered shares, A$9.37 of the buyback price is treated as a fully franked dividend for tax purposes.     -By Alex Wilson, Dow Jones Newswires; 61-3-9671-4313; alex.wilson@dowjones.com   -Edited by Paul Dekkers     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 01, 2007 18:50 ET (22:50 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Japan's Hitachi: Mulling If To Sell Large LCD TVs
Story: TOKYO (Dow Jones)--Hitachi Ltd. (6501.TO) said Monday it is considering selling large-screen TVs based on liquid crystal display technology.   The Tokyo-based electronics conglomerate currently relies on plasma technology for TVs over 40 inches diagonally, but said it may begin selling LCD TVs at such sizes as well.   Plasma technology was once considered to be better suited for large-screen TVs. But LCD technology is becoming increasingly suited to larger products as it matures and production methods become more advanced.   "According to market conditions, we are considering" such sales, said a company spokesman, adding that when and in what locations the new TVs would be sold had yet to be determined.   The comments came after the Yomiuri Shimbun reported that Hitachi would begin selling large-screen LCD TVs in China and Europe in autumn.     -By Jay Alabaster, Dow Jones Newswires; 813-5255-2929; jay.alabaster@dowjones.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 01, 2007 21:41 ET (01:41 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Softbank To Raise Y200B,Securitize Handset Receivables-Nikkei
Story: TOKYO (Nikkei)--Softbank Corp. (9984.TO) plans to procure some Y200 billion this fiscal year by securitizing receivables from installment sales of cellular phones, the Nikkei Financial Daily reported in its Monday edition.   The company had already raised Y88.1 billion as of Friday. Proceeds will be used to repay the debt it took on to acquire the mobile phone business last year.   Softbank's wireless subsidiary, Softbank Mobile Corp., offers installment payment plans of up to 24 months for handsets. Installment contracts recorded as receivables totaled Y177.2 billion as of March 31.   Softbank Mobile transferred the receivables to a trust set up by Mizuho Trust & Banking Co. (8404.TO), which was divided into preferred and subordinate portions.   Of the preferred portion,Y 65.1 billion in receivables were sold to institutional investors as asset-backed securities and loans. Another Y23 billion in receivables are incorporated into a monetary trust product of Mizuho Trust for sale to individual investors.   The products sold to institutional investors received an Aaa rating from Moody's Investors Service Inc., while the portion for individuals obtained an A rating from Rating and Investment Information Inc.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 01, 2007 17:59 ET (21:59 GMT)

Headline: UPDATE: Sojitz To Take 10% Stake In Australia Coal Mine
Story: (Adds production schedule, sales volume to Japan.)     TOKYO (Dow Jones)--Sojitz Corp. (2768.TO) Monday said it plans to invest about Y14 billion in the large Moolarben coal mine in New South Wales, Australia.   Sojitz will take a 10% stake in the mine for about Y9 billion and take on some Y5 billion out of the roughly Y50 billion in development costs, said a company spokesman.   Coal prices have surged recent years amid increasing demand for the fuel, especially from India and China.   Late last week, Sojitz singed a contract with Felix Resources Ltd. (FLX.AU), the operator of the mine, the Sojitz spokesman said.   Production at Moolarben will start in 2009, and is expected to reach full capacity of 12 million metric tons a year of thermal coal in 2011.   Of the total production, Sojitz expects to sell about 5 million tons to Asia annually, of which 3 million tons is expected to be shipped to Japan, the spokesman said.   -By Mari Iwata, Dow Jones Newswires; 813-5255-2929; mari.iwata@dowjones.com   -Edited by Tracy Gan     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 01, 2007 21:34 ET (01:34 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: NZ Auckland Airport Landing Fees To Rise 2.5%/Yr Next 5 Yrs
Story: WELLINGTON (Dow Jones)--Auckland International Airport Ltd. (AIA.NZ) said Monday that landing fees it charges airlines will rise by 2.5% a year for the next five years under its latest aeronautical pricing reset.   New Zealand's main international gateway said in a statement that the new prices will apply from September 1, 2007, but it now won't use asset revaluations to determine aeronautical pricing for the next 10 years.   "We hope that this approach will remove much of the uncertainty and tension in the price setting process going forward," said Auckland Airport chief financial officer Robert Sinclair.   The company also said departure fees will remain at NZ$25 per departing passenger until July 1, 2008 and will be levied on the airlines, removing the need for passengers to pay the charge at the airport.     -By Symon Ross, Dow Jones Newswires; 64-4-471-5990; symon.ross@dowjones.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 01, 2007 17:36 ET (21:36 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: : Elron Enters the Field of Internet and Cellular Through an Initial Investment in Journeys, a Massive Multiplayer On-Line Gaming (MMOG) Venture
Story: TEL AVIV, Israel--(BUSINESS WIRE)--July 01, 2007--   Elron Electronic Industries Ltd. (TASE & NASDAQ: ELRN), announced today that it has made its first investment in the internet and cellular field by providing a convertible loan of $600,000 to Journeys Ltd., an Israeli company which is in the Massive Multiplayer On-line Gaming (MMOG) arena. Journeys is engaged in the development of a casual internet multiplayer game appealing to a wide audience.     Journeys was established earlier this year by three Israeli entrepreneurs, Guy Bendov, one of the founders of Double Fusion specializing in in-game advertising, Sharon Priel, former Vice President of Technology of The Marker, a leading Israeli financial online and print publication and Assaf Priel, one of the founders of Inkod-Hypera, a well-known Israeli visual concept house.     Assaf Topaz, Vice President of Elron said: "The Journeys team is creative with significant technological experience and a proven track record. Journeys is developing the next generation of computer games integrating a unique game experience with advanced abilities in creating social networking. The combination of this winning team and the unique product they are developing is expected to make this company one of the major players in this field. "     Elron Electronic Industries Ltd. (TASE & NASDAQ: ELRN), a member of the IDB Holding group, is a leading Israel-based technology holding company directly involved in the long-term performance of its group companies. Elron identifies potential technologies, creates strategic partnerships, secures financing, and recruits highly qualified management teams. Elron's group companies currently comprise a diverse range of publicly-traded and privately held companies primarily in the fields of medical devices, information & communications technology, clean technology and semiconductors. For further information, please visit www.elron.com       (Any statements in this press release that may be considered  forward-looking statements are subject to risks and uncertainties that  could cause actual results to differ materially. Actual results may  differ from such forward-looking statements due to the risk factors  discussed in periodic reports filed by the Company with the Securities  and Exchange Commission, which the Company urges investors to  consider).        CONTACT: Elron Electronic Industries Ltd.               Rinat Remler, 972-3-6075555               Vice President & CFO               elron@elron.net        SOURCE: Elron Electronic Industries Ltd.  Copyright Business Wire 2007     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 01, 2007 05:20 ET (09:20 GMT)

Headline: S&P Assigns Citibank Japan AA/A-1+ On New Banking Operation
Story: TOKYO (Dow Jones)--Standard & Poor's Rating Services assigned ratings to Citibank Japan at the start of the company's local banking operation, the rating firm said Monday.   Citibank Japan is rated AA in the long-term and A-1+ in the short-term counterparty ratings. The outlook on its long-term rating is stable.   The rating was newly assigned to Citibank Japan, a member of U.S. financial services giant Citigroup (C), as the bank took over the banking operations from Citibank N.A. July 1.   Citigroup, which completed its purchase of Nikko Cordial in May, is rated AA with a stable outlook and was unaffected by the takeover.   Following the new ratings on Citibank Japan, S&P withdrew its AA long-term and A-1+ short-term ratings on Citibank N.A. at the company's request.   -By Megumi Fujikawa, Dow Jones Newswires; 813-5255-2929; megumi.fujikawa@dowjones.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 01, 2007 23:07 ET (03:07 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Morgan Stanley Aims To Buy 10% Of Taiwan Chinatrust - Report
Story: TAIPEI (Dow Jones)--Morgan Stanley (MS) has applied to Taiwan's investment commission to acquire a nearly 10% stake in Chinatrust Financial Holding Co. (2891.TW) for about NT$20 billion (US$611 million), the Economic Daily News reported Monday, without citing sources.   The U.S. investment bank will also seek seats on Chinatrust's board next year, the newspaper said.   Jason Wang, Chinatrust's chief strategic officer, said the company has met several interested parties but hasn't discussed the details of a sale with any investor, the newspaper reported.   Morgan Stanley officials couldn't immediately be reached for comment, the newspaper said.       Newspaper Web site: http://www.udn.com       -By Taipei bureau, Dow Jones Newswires; 8862-2502-2557; djnews.taipei@dowjones.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 01, 2007 21:03 ET (01:03 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.
